reviewText:
First of all, it was about time for this to come out! I was beginning to think it wasn't going to come out this year.

This is a great series very exciting, great special effects and the writing is by far better than most of SG1's first 2 seasons, sure this is because now the writers team are so familiar with the stargate universe It's easier to go on sci-fi mode for them ( I guess). Also the characters are great sure some need more developing, but hey! its just beginning and there are lots of people in atlantis, my personal favorites are Rodney and Sheppard.

I also love the fact that even though the team is in some very serious situations, the series is not horribly heavy to watch but actually has a enjoyable sence of humor and the chemistry between different characters is great.

Season 2 is doing awesome! sad is going on mid season break until january =(.

but if you buy this you can catch up on season 2 on the reruns if you haven't seen it that is.

Anyway I recommend this new series even though I refused to give it a chance when it was first aired (caught it on re-runs and loved it) Its even great for people who have never seen Sg1. I can't wait to get it and hear the commentaries specially Peter de Luis he cracks me up.

In a nutshell: " Great series, lots of action, fun to watch, very exciting beginning, bright future and excellent second season"

After all the popularity that Stargate: SG-1 received in its first six years on the air, it was only natural that the creators would want to expand the story with a spin-off series.  As SG-1's seventh season was going on, Stargate: Atlantis was being developed.  Using a plot twist that was introduced at the end of SG-1's seventh season, Atlantis got its start.

After searching throughout the Milky Way galaxy for the fabled Lost City of the Ancients (the ancients are a very advanced race of beings that died out long ago), Stargate Command realized that it is on Earth... or at least it was.  The city, which comes to be known as Atlantis, was built on Earth millions of years ago.  The ancients, who as I said are extremely advanced, ot only made it a city, but also made it a spaceship capable of intergalactic travel.  When a great plague hit Earth, some of the ancients evacuated in Atlantis to the Pegasus galaxy, where they plan to start a civilization similar to the one that they had in the Milky Way.

Dr. Daniel Jackson (Michael Shanks) of SG-1 eventually finds the correct gate address to Atlantis and an international team of explorers is put together in order to go to and study Atlantis.  The expedition will be led by Dr. Elizabeth Weir (Torri Higginson), a civilian who was very briefly in charge of the SGC.  The Chief Science Officer is Dr. Rodney McKay (David Hewlett), a civilian who has helped out the SGC in the past, the head surgeon is Dr. Carson Beckett (Paul McGillion), a Scottish MD and biologist, and the head of military operations is hardened Col. Summner (Robert Patrick).

In order to work most ancient technology efficiently, a rare gene is required, and while Dr. Beckett has it, it isn't pronounced enough to matter.  In comes Major John Sheppard (Joe Flanigan), a hotshot air force officer with insubordination issues.  Even though he could be a liability to the expedition, he not only has the gene, but can operate the ancient technology almost flawlessly, so he comes along as well.  The last major character is Lt. Aiden Ford (Rainbow Sun Franks), a young officer who looks up to Sheppard (and tragically was born without a personality).

Upon arrival in Atlantis, the team realizes that the power is nearly gone, and in order to survive, the city must use the electricity that was powering the defenisve shield to power life support systems.  This also means that they cannot use the gate to go back to Earth, since an intergalactic wormhole requires much more power than normal.

Soon, the team begins exploring the city (which is immense) as well as the planets in the galaxy.  On the first planet they visit, they meet Teyla (Rachel Luttrel), a young warrior woman who protects her tribe from something called the Wraith.  When Teyla learns that the visitors don't know who the Wraith are, she begs them to return to where they came from.  Soon, the Wraith show up and a lot of bad things ensue.  The Wraith are a race of beings that actually gave the ancients a good fight!  They are humanoid in build, but they are stronger, faster, and more resistant to harm than any human could hope to be.  Also, humans are their food; they literally suck the life out of people.  Fortunately for the people of the Pegasus galaxy, they only come around every half century or so (most of them hibernate for long periods of time).  Unfortunately, in an act of heroism, Sheppard accidentally causes the entire Wraith population to wake up and begin to feed all at once.

That is the pilot episode.  After that, the series becomes somewhat similar to SG-1, where Sheppard and his team go to different planets to make alliances, trade for food, and help people escape the Wraith (I will say that for such a powerful race, Sheppard and co. don't have too much trouble fighting them off).

A few story arcs develop this year.  One of them has the Atlantis expedition team get into a bitter rivalry with another advanced race of humans, which leads to an attempted coup on Atlantis.  Also, Beckett begins to study the Wraith and finds out how they came to appear human and how they were able to amass such great numbers.

I want to say that even though I'm giving this a 4 star rating, it is definitely a low 4.  The stand-alone episodes were usually moderate; some were good, some were just terrible, but on average, they were just ok.  The story-arc episodes were pretty good, and they showed that Atlantis has a lot of potential as a show.  While there will be a lot to work on, such as writing, character development, and stand-alone quality, after watching the first part of Season 2, I must say that I am very much enjoying where the series is going.  If for no other reason, this set should be watched in order to know what's going on in the later seasons, which so far, appear to be leagues ahead of this one.
I am sorry this is absolutely wrong.  Dont go buying this when it is obviously bootlegged.  It is probably poor quality and I am shocked that Amazon even is allowing this to stay on.
As the previous reviewers have mentioned, neither the pilot DVD nor the Season 1 DVD set has been released. This item appeared on Amazon immediately after the last episodes aired. Don't buy this.

Stargate Atlantis is a wonderful series and absolutely worth buying on DVD - BUT NOT FROM THIS CLOWN. This is a bootleg burned DVD set taken from TV.  It's probably crap quality, it doesn't have any extras and it's illegal for this guy to do this.

Save your money and do the right thing. Buy it when it's released by MGM later this year.
While it is true Atlantis is out in the UK it is only formated for region 2 so for this to be region 1 it has to have been bootleged.

Don't buy as this is illegal.  Like Crystal Obrien and others I'm just reviewing to bring the star rating down.  Please not that this rating is not a true reflection on the show and I will re-review when the real one comes out in late 2005.

I'm just writing this review to bring the star average down so less people think of buying this obvious rip off. Don't waste your time or money. I'm not normally one to write a review for no reason but malice, but with this I take exception. Amazon shouldn't even allow this. For shame!

JUST SAY NO!

I hope nobody buys this item - it is clearly a bootleg. The seller has negative feedback for selling burned copies of shows. This is not an import. While it is true that the first single-disc release of Atlantis has come out in the UK, it does not look like this and is not region 1.

The real Stargate Atlantis region 1 DVDs are not due until later this year. The first release, which contains the 88-minute pilot episode "Rising" is due on June 7th, and the full season 1 set is due in the Fall (rumors say November.) The pilot DVD will retail for around $25 (and cost much less on Amazon) and the boxed set has a suggested retail price of $70 and will probably go for about $50 on Amazon.

Don't give your money to these pirates for shoddy burned copies.

Stargate Atlantis was a great series. It only lasted half as long as Stargate SG1, and didn't have the wonderful cast of Stargate SG1, but I enjoyed the series as much as the original Stargate series. I only watched a few episodes of Stargate Universe. The original Stargate series was fun and witty. Stargate Atlantis continued with the fun and wit, but Stargate Universe was dark and dumb, with an unlikeable cast.

Stargate SG1 is a great example of taking a mediocre movie, the source material, and turning it into an outstanding franchise with the longest running sci-fi series in history, although Supernatural is now the longest running fantasy series in history.

When Im not watching episodic storytelling Im reading, everything from nonfiction to westerns, but at least half of my time is spent reading sci-fi and fantasy.

Sci-fi and fantasy authors I like include Douglas Adams, Isaac Asimov, Paolo Bacigalupi, Ray Bradbury, Orson Scott Card, Arthur C. Clarke, Earnest Cline, Suzanne Collins, Abe Evergreen, Diana Gabaldon, William R. Forstchen, Joe Haldeman, Robert A. Heinlein, Frank Herbert, Hugh Howey, George Martin, Larry Niven, Andre Norton, George Orwell, Patrick Rothfuss, Brandon Sanderson, John Scalzi, John Steakley, J.R.R. Tolkien, and Andy Weir.

I had been watching the StarGate SG1 series for quite some time and when I found out that SGA was a part of it, at first I wasn't sure if it would be good. I was so wrong. Stargate SGA is an incredible series and season 1 hits the ground running. This is a totally new cast, with a few exceptions (Rodney), but they were very well picked actors. The dynamics with the wraith create an intriguing atmosphere. If you love SG1, you will love this series!

This was less of a spin-off and more of a compliment to Stargate SG-1.  We were already introduced to the idea of Atlantis in the SG-1 series so this was a natural development of the franchise.  Season 1 starts off full throttle with humans poking around and waking an enemy of course.  This first season also introduces the beginnings of many recurring plots (the Genii, the Hoffan drug, etc.).  Not many spin-off type shows are as enjoyable as the original and Atlantis does benefit from multiple crossover themes and original SG-1 characters; but ultimately, Atlantis can hold its own without those crutches.

Based upon the movie 'Stargate' it closely follows the theme of the movie. Basically, teams from Earth called SG-teams travel to different worlds through a Stargate found on Earth. The show mostly follows the four members of SG-1. The shows are an hour and the team members battle some alien force or solve a critical problem somewhere. Their central Earth location is at the Cheyenne Mountain Air Force facility.

The plots are very interesting and the writing is excellent. Acting is first rate with a mix of drama and humor. The special effects are great for the time.

If you like SciFi, give SG-1 a try. I have watched all of the episodes over and over. 5 stars.

Must agree with other reviewers about the editing issues - it's been a few years since I've watched the series, so it's possible that I have not noticed all of the missing scenes, but there were two that were blatantly missing to me: 1) the scene with O'Neill and Sheppard in the helicopter after Sheppard is offered a position on the expedition and 2) the scene with Elizabeth's video recording to Simon and her voiceover message as other expedition members prepared for the trip and said goodbye to their loved ones. These scenes were especially important; they showcased Sheppard's skepticism about joining the expedition and his self-doubt that he had anything of value to contribute. Additionally, not only did Elizabeth's voiceover provided necessary history about Atlantis and the Ancients for anyone new to the show, but that scene also exhibited a personal side to Elizabeth and showcased the large sacrifices that the expedition members were making, and Joel Goldstein's beautiful music had made this scene all the more poignant and touching. It is a shame that these scenes not included here, and I am sorely disappointed that these essential scenes have been cut out from the pilot episode here on Amazon.

It is a very good spin off of the original Stargate series.  The main characters are all very likable and have good chemisty, even the Doctor who is a whiny is likeable.  The main story starts with the discovery of the ancient city of Atlantis in the Pegasus galaxy, and earth sending a  large military and research contingent there knowing that they will only be able to do this once and that for the most part they will be on their own, until another way is found to bring them back or send support to them.  Upon arriving there in the city find that the city is underwater and that the shield holding back the water is failing.  Unexpectedly the city raises to the surface.  They are only able to power some of the cities areas with the generators that they brought.  As they go out exploring they are met by a Wraith raiding party that takes some of the off world team.  In rescuing them back they inadvertently awaken the whole hive.  They find out that the Wraith are the ones that defeated the Ancients, and in a last ditch effort the Ancients had submerged the city and fled back to Earth, those that were left.  The teams as they go out exploring looking for allies and energy modules to power the city run into allies and foes alike.  The season ends with the Wraith coming to capture Atlantis in hopes of finding a way to Earth to open a new feeding ground for them.

If you like SG-1, you will enjoy Stargate Atlantis. You have a season of new people getting to know each other and trying to make new friends by building alliances,while trying to make the found long lost city, home.

I think this has it all. You quickly become attached to the characters and feel their experiences. Atlantis has a lot to be discovered and there are a lot of people who have wanted to find it. So, you have to become acquainted to your new home, protect your new home, try to make sure you follow the military guidelines, protect your people at home and when exploring "off world".....phew! I think you are getting my point.

There is a lot of action, funny interactions and every other emotion you can think of. You will be hooked. Sit back and enjoy the ride. Umm...I forgot to ask you...do you have the ancient gene?

I am a hardcore fan of this show from the very beginning, you could say I am addicted. Whenever I am feeling down and depressed, I watch a few episodes and I feel so much better. Cancelling this series was a monumental mistake!

Admittedly I like anything to do with Stargate stories. The entire premise of ancient technology taps into so many of the mysteries that both scientist and archeologist are unable to explain. The SG series combined great story line with generally good acting, great music, and good cinematography. The characters in Stargate Atlantis are dreadfully human, often lovable and sometimes frustrating. SG-1 and Atlantis are grounded, for good or bad, in the hard to believe universe that amazingly speaks English, a necessary presupposition to enable a fluid and exciting story line. But tuck that aside and enjoy the shows. Atlantis replaces Colonel O'Neil with Major Sheppard, right down to the cowlick hairdo and rebellious leadership styles, so for the SG fanbase it was a nice transition. The Wraith are the clear replacement of the Goa'uld. They lack the complexity of character but they have the essential evil and fear factor.  As with any series, it's hard to compete with a movie production. To carry on the story requires great writing and production. And some patience on the part of viewers and fans like myself who would might not like every episode. But this is a great series. The characters remain true to their personalities and key characters show development over time. There is a main character for every taste from prophet to warrior, idealist to pragmatism.

This is an excellent first season for the Stargate SG-1 spinoff.  The central characters are obviously crafted to appeal to the fans of Stargate SG-1.  Nevertheless, they develop their own distinctive personalities as the season progresses.  The season contains all the drama, humor, and action fans have come to expect from this long-running science fiction franchise.  Perhaps due to improvements in technology, this series is even able to top the original in terms of special effects.  Highly recommended for fans of the original series (but make sure you have watched seasons 1 to 8 of Stargate SG-1 before you start on Stargate Atlantis).

There are certainly scenarios and characters in SG1 that are not believable, but at least in SG1, I wanted to believe.  In Atlantis, I could care less. At this point, I'll probably just move on to season 2 to see if the episodes improve.  If not, I'll just sadly say, "goodbye," to Stargate Atlantis and return to complete SG1.

Okay - I admit it.  I am a Stargate addict.  It's so great to be able to go through the entire series one season after the other.  Naturally, I highly recommend that you first watch several seasons of Stargate SG-1 to get the context if you're not familiar with the shows.  There is quite a bit of "outer space" violence, little sex and a small amount of language, so you might want to limit this to ages 14 and up.  Although, today's kids are so used to violence in video games and such, you might be able to get away with age 10 and up.  Parents discretion.  These are two long running series that just grab you.  It's also helpful to watch the movie "Stargate" before embarking on the TV series!

Stargate atlantis is a pretty good series. BUT, the fact is for an expedition / endeavor that is to be the most important in human history, Dr.
Weir was absolutely the wrong choice for a mission leader. Think about this, just 6 months prior to Dr. Weir heading off to lead this expedition she was beginning her command of stargate command (Right after the 3 month "review board") So, she poorly runs the SGC for a grand total of 6 months, only to resign and then be selected to "lead" the atlantis expedition. Now having only known about the stargate / new reality for 9 or 10 months, your telling me the world leaders and international comity select a "business broker", to go find and retrieve atlantis? BS

At this point in the stargate series the ONLY clear choice would be SG1 and Hammond to lead this expidition. As oppsosed to Dr. Weir's supposed knowledge of "ancient tech" having only studied the antartic outpost for a month, wouldn't Dr. Daniel Jackson, having already studied "ancient tech" for 10 years have been a more reasonable choice. Wouldn't General Hammonds knowledge of having lead stargate command for 8 or 9 years have been a better mission commander? Also, as an alterative, retired general Jack Oneill would have filled the mission commander just fine as a civilian.

Lets face it, with an ego so large that he thinks he's gods gift to save the "universe", Rodney McCey is a jack ass who nobody even wants to watch his idiot personality. Furthermore in 80% of the situations he supposedly "Saves the day". He CAUSED them to begin with, by screwing with stuff way over his head. Samantha Charter had already proven herself from before the stargate was opened, maybe what? 15 years experience? Samantha Carter should have been the leader of the front line gate team at atlantis. Teal'c having no real interest in the pegasus galaxy would have probably stayed behind. No problem, the best member of the entire atlantis expedition was already there, "Roanan" . Isn't it interesting that the 2 most reasonable, and persistently have the moral high ground over all the others, and rightly so, is "Roanan and kayla"  and they weren't even part of the atlantis expedition to begin with. But most of all Dr. Weir has no business running any expedition, much less one of this importance. Do i have a problem with female leaders? Nope, Samantha Carter is a far better leader. I say, if SG1 had been the ones selected to recover Atlantis, it would have been back to earth in under 6 months.

Here is just one instance of ludacris leadership by Dr. Weir. Season 2 episode "Inferno" introduces the atlantian warship renamed as the "Orion". Now, Orion having 1 or 2 "ZPM's". Is sitting there hidden and parked light years away and wraith ship is on long range scanners. The very next Episode "Season 2 episode 'Allies'", last episode of season 2, here comes the Wraith ship, hails them, say's they want to negotiate / blackmail them. So Dr. Weir is in the position that the single hive ship has blackmailed her that they will give away altantis' location if they do not comply. Well At her disposal is the 1 or 2 ZPM's in warship Orion, as well as the earth starship Daedalus is there. Wether its 1 or 2 ZPM's doesn't matter, the city can intersteller flight AND launch Drone weapons. So you take the ZPM from the hidden Orion ship. Use Atlantis and Daedalus to destroy the single wraith hive. Open hyperspace window to a new location with both Atlantis and Daedalus. Once Atlantis is relocated you take the ZPM onboard Daedalus and Hyperspace Daedalus back to the Orion. Then Hyperspace both back to orbit the new planet Atlantis is on. Problem solved, Atlantis hidden again with 2 warships in orbit as a protective cover.

So, instead how does Dr. Weir handle it? Dr. Weir trusts the enemy, "Even though the whole conversation started with blackmail", and ends up with a 1.5 years of dealing with "Michael the half converted Wraith" and in the end having to sacrifice Orion to protect Atlantis. (And having to relocate atlantis ANYWAY)

So after having stuck around so long that they awakened every enemy in the entire pegasus galaxy , "Including a replicator home planet" who does the earth international comity replace her with? Oprah listening homo Richard Woolsie. Who just happens to be the only person they could find who was WORSE than Dr. Weir. (Which is questionable because at least he got atlantis back to earth)

At nearly 5 of 5 stars, few shows ever reach that status. And yet, even though the series was a ratings success for the Sci Fi Channel, it was cancelled in the 5th season. Here on Amazon as well as elsewhere, SG-A rates as high as SG-1, which completed 10 seasons and had several follow-up movies. Just goes to show you that the "Top Brass" at most networks are out of touch with the viewing public, relying too heavily on external ratings outfits. In the US, Nielsen uses a technique called statistical sampling to rate shows; Nielsen creates a "sample audience" and then counts how many in that audience view each program, then extrapolates from the sample and estimates the number of viewers in the entire population watching the show. This process can potentially be precise, but it can also be wildly inaccurate. It sure was here! With the afterglow of SG-1, and the mythology ever expanding, SG-A had also, the greatest of all enemies: The Wraith! I believe they could have even defeated The Borg!

Pretty decent sci-fi show. Slightly campy at times and the production values aren't always great, but the characters are interesting and the plots are usually better than they sound. The first season has a nice tension between the civilians of Atlantis, who are there to explore the alien worlds and learn the science, led by Elizabeth Weir, a very smart, competent leader who emphasizes diplomatic resolution and long-term peace, and the Marines, led by John Sheppard, also smart and competent, but more willing to use violence and brute strength. The mission is under civilian jurisdiction, so technically Elizabeth is in charge except during security threats, and she and John balance each other really well, actually, when they aren't arguing about what constitutes a security threat, and John bothers to actually follow orders. The show does a really good job with the alien bad guys, the Wraith, who are genuinely creepy and have enough presence to create a sense of mild dread even when they aren't in an episode, and the human bad guys end up being pretty worrisome themselves.

The humor is pretty good, especially when it's aimed at Rodney, head scientist and the self-proclaimed 'smartest man in the universe', who can be pompous and whiny; John spends a lot of time laughing at him behind his back (and sometimes to his face), but like all the characters on this show, Rodney's a balance of flaws and heroism. The cast has pretty good chemistry overall, and the balance of humor and tension is good. There are a few kind of slow episodes, but they build to a pretty satisfying cliffhanger by the end. If you're a sci-fi fan, you should give it a shot.

The series is great and I have watched it more than a few times. BUT, please be aware that a small portion is cut from this first episode that I think sets the stage well for the series. Missing is a conversation between O'Neill and Sheppard. Missing also is a video montage of key characters as they prepare to leave their lives on Earth and a video from Weir to her fiance. Other than that, I'm thrilled that more people get a chance to see this series.  Other than that, there is plenty of "tech", action, evil aliens, lessons to be learned and humor to go around. It was a fine ensemble cast in a series that ended too soon.

The episodes I watched of Atlantis became unbearable to watch...it was literally all about one person who was basically a pretty cocky, jerky guy to me...even worse than the replacement for Oneil in SG-1 since at least there was still the relationships of the other characters as part of the show...what made SG-1 so good was the relationships between all the team-members....like the original Star Trek. This vital ingredient is totally non-existent in the episodes of Atlantis that I have watched.  Atlantis is basically mindless, soulless action, with no depth or development of individuals or relationships...very surface and shallow. So I have moved on from the franchise and will not order further Atlantis episodes unless they are practically being given away.

I have watched this series on Amazon Prime several times, since discovering it in Summer of 2014.  I love Joe Flanigan after "discovering" him in this series and have gone back to look at his prior acting roles on Prime, YouTube, DVD and TV.  Actually, I love all the actors after seeing how well they made these characters come to life and have done the same for their past roles and will follow them in future roles.  I am sad that "Stargate: Atlantis" only lasted five years  and had no follow up movies to wrap up that series finale.  A sci-fi series with action, aliens, humor and heart!

It is not Stargate SG-1, but of what I have seen of it so far (about a half dozen episodes of season one), it does have its good points.  Because I was a big SG-1 fan, I kinda resented what appeared to be just a copycat series, so I never watched it when it was broadcast.  There have been some character crossovers from SG-1 in the pilot episode, and I understand that later in the series Amanda Tappiing returns as Col. Samantha Carter (not sure of her rank in Stargate Atlantis...just calling on her final rank from SG-1).  I didn't want to just start with her episodes without knowing what led to her character's entrance into Stargate Atlantis, so I will at least watch it through those episodes.  If my reckoning of Stargate /Atlantis changes as I watch the episodes until then, I'll do my best to update this post.

Stays well within the canon of the Stargate franchise, provides a new set of personalities but the SGA Team 1 is almost a mirror copy of SG-1.  Would liked to have seen a bit more variance and creativity in that regard, and maybe a bit more creativity in the "dooms day" style. You could literally replace Wraith with Goa'uld and never know you were watching a different franchise other than set difference.  Maj. Sheppard is a very close resemblance of Col. O'Neil in regards to playing the funny, military leader smart, sometimes science dumb part that we saw Richard Anderson play in SG1 season 1.  But it works in the dynamics of the rest of the cast very well.
If you are a Stargate fan, then you will love this one seriously.  Wish it would have gone for 10 seasons.  Dang shame they ran out of creativity and ability to keep it on the air.

The opening scene for Episode 1 hooked me within two seconds.  I had never seen any of the Stargate shows, not even the movie that started it all, before I saw Atlantis.  (I know, hard to believe but it is sad and true.)  I have since watched them all, and am now making my third lap through watching Atlantis, and I love it almost as much now as the first time!  The casting, directing, and acting are all top-shelf, and the sets and special effects are spectacular.  Atlantis is true escapist entertainment, as good IMO as anything else in that genre on the small screen.  I should warn you, Atlantis viewing can be habit forming!  And since no good thing can last forever, when you finish the last episode of the last season, you WILL have withdrawals!

I know it's somewhat of a dated series but I have alway's wanted to watch Stargate Atlantis since I first saw the previews.  The CGI and props are pretty amazing.  All in all it's a great series with lot's of good entertainment value and I love the steampunk parts interjected into it.  I would have given it 5 stars except as much as I do like the actors I just haven't fallen in love with them like I have on other series's that I have watched.  Given their situation and the fact that they have just vaulted across the universe into a strange new world I felt the actor's should have been more in awe and their expressions should have been more in tune to their predicement and the fact that hey their not in Kansas anymore.  Everyone speaks english no matter where they go and no one is amazed or stunned by what new things they run across, but as I stated it's dated and it seems all of the older series had this same mo so to speak.

I watched maybe one or two episodes when it first came out and stopped watching. I just didn't think it was very good. This after watching SG1 semi-religiously.

I was wrong. It is different from SG1, certainly. Thanks to Prime, my wife and I have watched Atlantis Season 1..and 2...and are now on 3. She doesn't even much like sci-fi--or didn't--and we are going through the whole thing.

The cast was not quite as strong as SG1. The original Dr. Weir, I thought, was a stronger character and Dr. McKay is about 10 times more annoying than I see any reason for him to be. Hewlett is a good actor, though. He plays a PITA well--why they wrote that character that was is a mystery to me. The cast evens out mostly and the stories are quite interesting. That is the strong point. You just never know if  you are going to get something cute or ominous or droll. We really are enjoying it.

As a huge fan of science fiction shows who has grown tired of waiting for a new sci-fi or space opera series, I decided to check out some of the classic shows I missed during their original runs, including Stargate Atlantis (SGA).

My first introduction to Stargate was actually Stargate Universe (SGU).  While I didn't hate it, I also was coming off of the amazing BSG, and SGU was somewhat of a let-down, being too dark and not having enough serialization. Several years later, and still no BSG-quality science fiction series has come out, so I have decided to start fresh with SGA.

First off, SGA looks stunning. From the sets, special effects, and costumes to the production quality itself, SGA is beautiful.

Then, there's the main character: John Sheppard, played by handsome, likable, and funny actor Joe Flanigan. John is what I think of as the typical American hero: he's got strong sense of what's right, he doesn't play by the rules, and he's always willing to put himself in danger for his team.  There's something very appealing about an unapologetic hero.  John is supported by a team of characters that includes doctors, researchers, military personnel, and alien natives.  While not all of them won me over (I know he's a fan favorite, but I strongly disliked the arrogant genius, Dr. McKay, for a long time and after 1 season I still find Dr. Weir to be a complete bore), several stand out including the wise, strong, and courageous Teyla, the reliable, humorous Dr. Beckett, and innocent, young soldier, Ford.

The villains, The Wraiths, look pretty terrifying and make a good enemy for our heroes.  As the season progresses, we get some good conflicts with them and exciting action sequences.

Atlantis itself is exciting to behold, as well as the various worlds the team finds themselves exploring, defending, and being trapped on. There is a rich mythology that is fun to discover throughout the season.

One complaint I have is there are a lot of filler, stand-alone episodes.  I tend to prefer serialized stories, but thankfully most of the individual stories provide good character moments that pay off later.

I look forward to continuing on with season 2, and then at some point giving SG-1 a go and SGU another chance.

Other science fiction I enjoy: Syfy's Battlestar Galactica, Lost, Fringe, Terminator: The Sarah Connor Chronicles, Farscape

A huge fan of Stargate: SG1, I finally decided to check out Atlantis. I was very pleased. I really like the characters and the plot. It feels a LOT like SG1 as far as the type of action, how fast the plot moves, etc. Some might find this disappointing, but being such a big fan of SG1, I liked that element. I just purchased Season 2 and am looking forward to watching it as well. The only reason I gave it 4 stars instead of 5 is because SG1 remains my favorite. But Atlantis is growing on me. If you haven't seen SG1, references to types of aliens and/or technology might make it a bit hard to follow in places, but after a few episodes it would start to make more sense.

I'm a lifelong sci-fi geek, but there's a lot of tv sci-fi I just can't tolerate. I like the original Stargate movie, and pretty much hate the first series spun off from it -- hate the characters, hate the cast, hate the cheesy writing. Even though it's a spinoff of a spinoff, I think Atlantis is a step up. Better cast, better sets and graphics, more interesting storyline and somewhat less insultingly dumbbell writing. Sure, I was hoping well before the end of season 1 that the Rodney character would get eaten by a Wraith (he doesn't, and continues through the entire series to be just as aggravating and one-note) and that the Shepard dude would find a comb somewhere in the city (he doesn't, but at least other characters sometimes make fun of his hair). And by the last season it loses its way and muddles around terribly, the way a lot of long-lived tv shows do. I mean I still would rather watch something from the Star Trek franchise, but for tv sci-fi this isn't bad.

It is very difficult for a movie that has been successful to continue on with and not become dreadfully boring after awhile. Often the follow ons attempt to use whatever had been successful in the preceding movie. However, the first with its novelty will have an interest solely because it is the first. With Stargate the follow ons were formed into multiple shorter episodes that allowed the constructive individuals to use the movie solely as the first address on the Gate with an unlimited number of new destinations as well as new story lines.
The jump to a completely new portion of the universe allowed the writers to introduce new species that were very different from those that populated the initial Galaxy, both in appearance, but to a greater extent, their unique abilities. To make this possible required the human like and a very advanced species to have fought these "unstoppable" beings only to be exterminated or were they? That however does introduce a considerable inconsistency that the backward "Humans"  are holding their own while the advanced "Atlantans" were destroyed?

I absolutely love this show. The script and plots aren't the most original...and the acting isn't the greatest. Having said that, I love this show with all my heart and soul. I've been marathoning it for the past week!

Each episode is highly entertaining. The show doesn't take itself too seriously, which is a huge relief. And although the characters are not overly complex, I, for one, am SO VERY glad that they are not overly complex, tortured beings who over-contemplate humanity and their influences on other worlds, blah blah blah. The show touches upon the influence of humanity, human compassion, etc., but also delves satisfyingly into just plain, good ol' fashioned conflict-resolution action. This allows me hours of mind-numbing, stress-free television fun.

I also love the all-for-one-and-one-for-all attitude of the group and in-your-face archetypes: the capable (but sometimes conflicted) leader, the charming rogue, the compassionate foreigner, the arrogant scientist, and the mysterious fighter.

Also, Jason Momoa. <3 That is all.

This is one of my favorite TV series.  I do not take time to watch many shows or movies; but I seem to want to re-watch Stargate whenever I can.  Streaming Atlantis (and the other Stargate series) is major reason why I jointed Amazon Prime. Please don't take it away!
Love Amazon prime for this show alone. My absolute fave of the Stargate shows. I miss it. Will look for more gems

I loved the original Stargate series and thought the idea of spinning off the whole Atlantis discovery from the original show was both good writing as going to an entire new Galaxy to explore certainly has enough storyline to support its own show plus as much as I love the original show it had a long good run, but the timing was great to bring closure to the original an this was a natural branching point.  Some of us may have liked to see the transition of some of the characters from the original show, but they did a good job of integrating the plots and use Atlantis to pump new life into the franchise.  The quality of the show stands on the success of the original series by leveraging many of the big discoveries from the original show allowing the off world base that can't easily stargate back and forth to earth make for great starting point to a show that stood on it's own.  Yes, no doubt that Sheppard has many of the personality traits as our original hero, but why kill a good thing?  Being off in another Galaxy somewhat isolated allows for the use and introduction of more of the ancients technology letting teh story grow in a way that the writers don't have to worry about reconciling with modern day earth.  Instead we have a new set of bad guys even nastier than the original, some fresh faces in familiar roles based on the whole stargate structure giving it a powerful launching point from the original show which I think they did an excellent job of building on allowing SG-1 continue on and fade away while Atlantis could grow it's own with new adventures and story lines that leave us able to have technology advances along the way allow for less isolation as the show progresses and their defensive capabilities and understanding of the Wraith continue to increase.  Being a spinoff of a successful show extending the show to a franchise of shows can produce other good shows as we saw with the second generation of Star Trek spinoff's.  Some better than others, but none the less still enough good to be an overall success.  I didn't have time to watch either of these shows when they were on TV so being able to watch them by streaming them allows me to fit them into my time line and watch all the shows, not just the ones I could fit in to my schedule.  So having seen many episodes in the original run I already knew I liked the show, but being able to watch them all allows me to move it a level higher and thoroughly enjoy the show and some of the interesting moral challenges it introduces along with the continual build up of allies, foes, and technology.  Just as in the original series the writing relies on a basic formula for many episodes but they still do a good job of having the show story tie into the overall story and events and choices made earlier.  Having the show start by the team accidentally awakening the Wraith allowed for a super nasty enemy to be found in this new galaxy while introducing secondary effects of it being early that buys time for the team to evolve and not walk into a universe fully infected with Wraith that they would simply be wiped out in (wouldn't have made for much of a show).  The need to protect the location of earth being one of those byproducts introduces the raising of the stakes and the excitement as protecting the outpost suddenly becomes an important underlying need as it protects earth from the under-fed Wraith.  Definitely raising the level of bad guys from other shows as the thought of being harvested and fed on by one of them is truly creepy.  Overall I think the first season did a great job of establishing Stargate Atlantis as its own show that could support itself without a long transition from the original and quickly build an independent story line that could have had a longer run, but still was in my opinion a successful one in terms of science fiction shows go.  It didn't have as long a run as the original, but as far as I've seen so far (and I still have 3 seasons to watch) they did a great job and I can only hope that they are able to end the show without corrupting the franchise legacy (I still have never seen the final episodes).  So for the first season given the perspective of being just over half way through the second I think it is great and the transition handled well.  I'm excited to have 3 more seasons to watch and can only hope the quality remains high and they can write a successful ending in terms of the franchise storyline.  I can only hope that SG Universe is not an indication of where this goes as I thought that show was a significant letdown from the first two as I never became vested in the characters like I did in the original or Atlantis.
Really compelling sci-fi.  A worthy component of the Stargate franchise.  Excellent story lines and some decent acting make it a must for science fiction lovers.

Yeah Amazon keeps asking how I rate this series one season at a time. I'll just cut to the chase. I'll critique the whole series. After several viewings, I find the episodes that did not include wars with the wraith and repilcators to be, how shall I say, MEH.  Oh the virus is going to get us episodes were ok. So was the whalething episode. I realize they can't be fighting all the time but all those medieval villages with the same background music got to be annoying, so either cultures flew around in space ships or dug in the dirt with sticks. Love the characters (they make the show) and the all the star Wars and Star Trek references, Sheppard- "He's on my ship!" McCay -"What are you, Captain Kirk?" and McCay's use of Kirk's name as a verb, "Don't Kirk my sister" Series could have used better episode writers but the characters are great, Joe Flannigan's endless mugging and Momoa's Chewbaca like persona. All in all the whole series has it's good points and bad. I've found coutless editing errors, Carson in 2 places at once and see through lighting rod couplings. The network where this series originally ran made a grave mistake cancelling this show, and I wish it would get revived again like Star Trek did. This show had a longer run than Star Trek and I know lots of people who love this show still. Let's face it, lots of us are 12 yrs old inside and that will not change no matter how old we get. I know a few who like me, suffer from voracious repeatisitis. Rock on

As a spin-off of SG-1 it has its own dramatic platform with well developed characters with strong personalities.  The narrative's continuity of blending our culture's futuristic ultra-high tech vision with other civilizations, like the Athosians led by Teyla, whom rely more on personal inner strengths and wisdom gives it balance.  The portrayal of Elizabeth Weir as a leader highlights the challenges that woman have in filling that role.  Torri Higginson does a solid commendable job in portraying an astute low-techie human leader in contrast to the dazzling super-tech skills of Sam Carter.  Of course Carter is a continuation of her character from SG-1 with her strong, dynamic intellectual persona.
  Unlike the personable character of Daniel in SG-1, the extremely egotistical Rodney McKay is a much harder performance to pull off continually.  However, David Hewlett does a great job showing the various sides of Rodney's frailties.  My only criticism of his performance is that he talks too fast like he's cranked on speed.  Likewise, the Scottish character Beckett has such a thick accent that he's sometimes hard to follow.  Although a lot of their jargon is sci-fi techie-speak that doesn't have any basis in reality, often important story line logic gets lost in their verbal shuffle.  You sometimes have to diagram their sentences to figure out what they're meaning to say.
  Many characters reccur intermittently from SG-1, making it difficult for writers to maintain Atlantis' own identity and integrity.  The only two characters that Atlantis writers failed to make a strong enough distinction between the two drama series are Atlantis's Col. John Sheppard and Col. Cam Mitchell from SG-1.  Or is it the other way around?  The two could be interchangeable between any of the story-line narratives on either series and you wouldn't notice the difference.
  While solid acting behind strong well written characters is Atlantis's strength, its' one fundamental weakness is a story line that is hyper-focused on the Wraith who hunt for "feeding grounds" of humans to eat.  By comparison the SG-1 had at least three major foes, the Goa'uld, the Replicators and the Ori to spread out their story lines.  That's probably why SG-1 lasted longer.  Regardless, Stargate Atlantis is very entertaining and always worth the watch.

Same basic idea as SGU (which I watched first somehow): the team gates into an environment filled with wonder and uses it as their home base while they:

a) explore it and find amazing new things there
b) explore other worlds via Stargate
c) have um, interesting encounters with other lifeforms, some of which are pleasant, but most of which are not
d) battle evil aliens intent on eating them
e) learn to get along as a mix of military and civilians

This last point is a large component of the plot of a lot of space opera/sci-fi series: All the Stargates, BSG, etc. It makes for lots of interesting drama and power struggles. This is a great series with solid writing, mostly good acting, and a semi-episodical format, much like the two mentioned above, and many, many other series' that detail the ongoing saga of a group of explorers. In some cases the explorers are simply exploring the boundaries of science (X-files, Fringe), and in others, such as this, they are exploring unknown frontiers (Star Trek, etc.). This is a MUST-see for the sci-fi series fan (eg. me). Good TV.  And bonus: free with Prime. Love it.

I actually started my Stargate experience by watching Stargate Atlantis before I watched all 10 seasons of SG-1. I am now re-watching Atlantis because all the special appearances and references to SG-1 are much more meaningful now that I've watched SG-1.  I don't know why I wasn't watching this show while it was on TV, other than the fact that at the time I was (and still am) a huge Star Trek fan and treated all other SciFi as unworthy.  But watching Stargate (I watched all 10 seasons of SG-1 over the past 12 months after watching Atlantis first), I have to say this is an excellent series and I am very, very sorry I wasn't watching this when it was on TV.  I feel the same way about Stargate SG-1 and Atlantis as I do about Firefly...damn, I wish I was watching this when it was on rather than catching up years later on Amazon Prime.  Highly recommend this series to any fan of Science Fiction, but start with all 10 seasons of SG-1 first.

This is probably rated as sci fi but has to be scifi-fantasy. Yes, they travel through a Stargate to other worlds and meet other people, which may be hopefully sci fi (wouldn't you love to be able to do that? I would) but those people speaking English is probably all fantasy. The villains, the Wraith, are wonderful fantasy too, or nightmare horror. So now we are talking scifi-fantasy-horror genre. But really they always escape and  you know they will, even though they may escape with some aftereffects. If you want some really good entertainment complete with humor, check this series out! By far, the Atlantis series in the Stargate franchise is the most enjoyable. It's mix of drama, action, adventure, and humor set it apart and make it the BEST of all the rest. The ongoing war between the Atlantis Team and the Wraith makes for good adventure, then mix in the struggles with the back-stabbing Genii and the shape-shifting nanite Replicators and you make it even better. The only problem I have with this series is that they ended it too soon, five seasons was not enough. They should bring back Atlantis for at least another season or two, a full length movie would be fine too, because there are many more stories to be told here, especially since the city of Atlantis doesn't belong where it finally ended up.

From the moment the city of Atlantis rises from the ocean like a Phoenix, I was hooked. What an incredible concept even though the series is a spinoff from SG1, in so many ways it's even better. In a different galaxy, facing the prospect they may never be able to return home...it takes incredible people to volunteer for something like that. The acting is phenomenal, in my opinion. Joe Flanigan as Major John Sheppard starts out as a somewhat cocky loner who ends up becoming the military commander of Atlantis after tragically having to kill his commander who was being tortured by a Wraith queen. It's amazing how he transforms himself during the course of season one to adjust to his new leadership role he never sought. The mistakes he makes along the way only makes him more human. The successes he has makes him the reluctant hero. Very well done and the series only gets better over the years. It should never have been canceled.

In my opinion, Stargate Atlantis is one of the best Sci-Fi TV series of all time.  Not a single boring episode; all are well-made, and the visual effects are excellent. I will definitely watch the remaining 4 seasons.

The Wraith suck the life out of a human, turns them old and then they die. Its a great show with a pretty much great cast.  The Wraith harvest the galaxy like a rancher harvests his cattle.  Except the team from Atlantis has woken all the wraith at once not a small portion of them that should have risen.  Too many wraith not enough humans to feed on. Only because so many other SciFi shows have really been boring for me. Well things changed right after the first episode. Thats all it took. I would highly recommend this series for anyone who enjoys really good action without the Rated R stuff. This show is very family friendly. This series mirrors the Stargate SG-1 series almost exactly.  At first, it even seems that the main character, Sheppard is even trying to take on the personality of Jack, which is very annoying.  No, they don't have T'ok, but they do have their own tribal character in Tela and a nerd like Daniel in McCay.  Eventually, they realize Tela can't hack it as a replacement T'ok, so they bring in another strong-silent type in the next season.

Also like SG-1, the first season is only mildly entertaining and extremely predictable.  Eventually though, McCay becomes endearing and Dr. Becket's accent carries many of the scenes (until they get rid of him for some inexplicable reason).  If you can make it through that first season though, you'll probably want to watch it until the end.

While again, it doesn't live up to the potential a stargate premise has, it does give you some geeky sci-fi to watch when there's nothing else.

P.S. In the last season, watch out for the clip show masquerading as a judgement on Atlantis and just skip the second to last episode altogether as it has nothing to do with the style, plot, or point of the rest of the season.  Thanks for wasting our time on that one writers!

The characters are being developed well and evolve through the story, which itself is intriguing and involves a range of fascinating existential, ethical, and (pseudo) scientific questions, much like SG1 did. The mechanism of the Wraith feeding is the greatest hole which is likely to be quite difficult to fill: seriously, a life energy sucking creature? That seems to belong more in Buffy Vampire Slayer than in a futuristic SciFi show. There a couple cliche plot lines characteristic of this genre, including incorporation of an alien in the team, etc., but they did not seem as unnatural as in other shows, e.g. SG Universe, another Stargate spinoff.  Despite all that, I enjoyed the show. It had very few silly filler episodes about nothing, and even those offered clues or bits of info useful for the unfolding of the story that follows. As I remember SG1's 1st, and especially 2nd, seasons had painfully boring and pointless filler episodes, and Atlantis seems to avoid that practice as much as a show of this nature can. 4 stars, I'll keep watching...

Like the original Stargate Series, this doesn't let the Stargate aficionado down. The same thrill and excitement exist as well as a certain chemistry that has come to be expected in all shows associated with the original Stragate.

I usually don't do spinoffs. They usually suck. Like most spinoffs, Atlantis borrows the same "freak of the week" formula as SG-1 only with a new, ever more formidable enemy: the Wraith - like vampires meet the Goa'uld, but without the whimsy. This time, they're in the new city of Atlantis and the new enemy is super strong and its their fault the Wraith are awakened (sorry for the spoiler, but you find this out the very first episode so no real surprise).

Anyhow, the dynamic is a little different and the storylines and arcs unsurprisingly similar to the first few seasons or so of SG-1, but the formula works, the characters are genuine (or at least earnest) and lovable, and the special effects are much better. This show is a close second to SG-1 in my book, but a worthy spinoff. I haven't tackled Universe yet, but we'll see.

For those that enjoyed SG-1, the lost city has been found. Featuring a new cast, the adventures continue in the Pegasus galaxy, with an all new enemy race, the Wraith. A must watch if you are a true Stargate fan.

I watched all five seasons of SGA as the episodes premiered on SciFi (and it was still SciFi back then), I bought the DVDs when they became available, and Rising remains among my top five episodes not just for SGA, but SG-1 and Universe as well.
I do have a major gripe with the version available for streaming via Prime however, and if there were a way to rate Amazon's service separately for this I'd knock it down to three stars.  (Don't get me wrong though, I do like the Prime service in general; this is strictly about this one show).
The reason?  The streamed version is the one for broadcast, not DVD release (there are blatant inserts for commercial breaks, complete with the title screen), and there are even scenes missing.  I haven't streamed any other episodes yet, and now I'm not sure I will, even if it is convenient when I travel, if it means getting an incomplete experience; this is the series premier, setting the tone for everything coming after, and they couldn't even bother to post the whole thing?!  Some of these scenes aren't major, but they all include dialog and a few contain important plot or character development information that may leave new viewers scratching their heads.

Final thought: SGA is and will always be an awesome show, but do it justice and watch it on DVD or BluRay.

I got started on Stargate SG-1 a couple years ago.  Though the early seasons were very cheesy, the cast and universe the show created really grew on me.  By the later seasons of the show they had refined their formula to something fun and humorous, yet satisfying on a much deeper level as well.

Stargate Atlantis is a continuation of this Universe. A new galaxy, a new cast, and new threats; with regular cameos by some familiar faces. This show is a must watch for any sci-fi fans.

One of the big arcs of the "Stargate SG-1" series was finding the Lost City of the Ancients, also known as Atlantis.

It also turned into fertile fodder for a spinoff series (come on, you KNEW they had to make one eventually), known as "Stargate: Atlantis." The first season has its duds and awkward moments -- much like its parent series -- but it proves to be a solid introduction to likable new heroes, a legendary city, and a new race of alien parasites.

At the Antarctic base, Daniel Jackson (Michael Shanks) has finally figured out the location of Atlantis -- in the Pegasus galaxy. General Jack O'Neill (Richard Dean Anderson) gives the go-ahead for an exploratory unit to go to Atlantis -- even though they don't have the power to return back to the Milky Way, and will be stranded there.

So Dr. Elizabeth Weir (Torri Higginson) leads an international group of scientists and military to another galaxy, and arrive in the sunken Ancient city of Atlantis. Unfortunately, after ten millennia Atlantis is running out of power, and soon the whole place will flood. The military unit, including Major John Sheppard (Joe Flanigan), goes scouting for a planet to evacuate to, and encounter the friendly natives.

Meanwhile, the irritable scientist Rodney McKay (David Hewlett) tries to somehow salvage the city -- only to have it rise from the ocean floor. But then the SG teams accidentally wake an ancient enemy -- the parasitic, vampiric Wraith, who destroyed the Ancients long ago. Cut off from Earth, the expedition settles into the Ancient city and tries to make the best of their situation.

Unfortunately, the Pegasus galaxy has plenty of its own dangers -- an energy-sucking "shadow," possible spies, life-sucking bugs, a destructive nanovirus, a mysterious goddess, suicidal kids, cannibal Wraith, and an Amishlike people who turn out to be ruthless soldiers. And the Wraith are closing in on Atlantis, intent on getting to Earth -- forcing Weir and Sheppard to arm the city for what may be its final stand.

"Stargate: Atlantis" has an easier introduction than most series, even spinoffs. The whole idea was introduced over a few seasons of "Stargate SG-1," and two of the characters (Weir and McKay) were also recurring characters. And thank God, there is no endless whining about how they may never see Earth again, as many series would do -- the Atlantis personnel just forge ahead, and deal with it.

It does have some flaws, mostly the same ones that "SG-1" had in ITS first season -- a few duds ("The romancing of the alien priestess? It's very 1967 of you"), and many others that are good sci-fi watchin', but not great. It takes a little time for the series to get comfortable, but by the last four or five episodes, it really takes off.

And it has plenty of sci-fi staples -- ugly nasty aliens, tightly wound scientists, little tubular ships, explosions, moral quandaries and a bit of classic-style horror. But it doesn't lose its laid-back style (Rodney massaging his feet during a conference), or its human side -- for example, one episode has everyone recording touching messages to send back to Earth.

And the dialogue is pretty great, with lots of one-liners and snappy exchanges. Most are from Rodney ("This device must be using an older version of Windows"), and Sheppard ("I am your death. That is all you need to know." "I prefer 'Steve'"). But there's humor from everyone ("Find another problem with it! Tell him that the power-loop interface isn't jiving with your walkabout!").

The cast is a bit uneven -- Higginson is given too little to do, and Rainbow Sun Francks just never works. But Flanigan has a nice O'Neillian sarcastic snap, Hewlett is hilarious as the mildly antisocial, ever-exasperated scientist, and Paul McGillion is simply adorable as a cuddly Scottish doctor. And while Rachel Luttrell starts off as just the token native love interest, she evolves nicely at the end of the season.

"Stargate Atlantis" has its shaky moments, and the actors were still getting a grip on their roles. But it's a solid first for a solid sci-fi series, gating out into a new galaxy.

>>CORRECTED!<< As of the date of this review, the episode description is incorrect (NOW CORRECT...such as it is).  The following paragraph is my synopsis [NO spoilers]; remaining paragraphs are my review [also no spoilers]:

In the episode "Thirty-eight Minutes," Major Sheppard has been immobilized by a chihuahua-sized insect and is dying. The puddle jumper transporting him back to Atlantis becomes stuck half way through the stargate. Since stargates can remain open only 38 minutes, Dr. McKay, also aboard the puddle jumper, works to free it while other crew members Teyla and Lt. Ford work with Dr. Beckett (who is on Atlantis) to save Major Sheppard in the unlikely event they should make it through the stargate before it closes, killing them all.

It should be noted that I am an unabashed fan of this series, but I didn't like this episode when I first saw it because it takes place primarily in a confined space. This is a personal peeve of mine because I see this style of plot as a "money-saver" episode designed to skimp on the costs of effects, new props, and on-location shoots. At this stage in the series, it was way too early, in my mind at the time, to be subjecting us to this type of penny pinching.

Now that I've had some time between my first viewing and my second, I can appreciate it for its true merits. The episode is suspenseful yet the script is typical of the witty banter evinced throughout the series despite the seriousness of the situation. The "science" that drove the plot was handled effectively (although I don't know if it violated any known laws at the time of its airing since I didn't see it when it first aired) yet didn't interfere with the story (although, I must admit I have fairly low standards where this type of thing is concerned since I love techno-babble). The actors had their characters well in hand (unlike the pilot).

All in all it was a decent story and worth the hour spent watching it. I still don't prefer these types of episodes, but I did enjoy it more the second time I watched it than I did the first; which is saying something, since I almost skipped watching it because I had disliked it so much the first time.

In fact, with my second viewing I realized that it did have several flashbacks which could have been explained without filming the scenes.  This made me wonder if there had originally been much more to the story that they ended up cutting for time constraints...in which case, I forgive them for subjecting us to the "money-saving" appearance of the episode...but now I wonder what the original story might have been...

I hate commercials but I almost would rather have them than just a black screen.  This is pretty silly.  At each commercial junction the screen goes black and lasts for a few minutes.  Then the story pops up again until the next time.  Stargate Atlantis isn't the best sci-fi show ever but it's entertaining enough the first time you watch it.  I really can't recommend the streaming here though.  Maybe Netflix plays straight through.

Great episode.  At first I thought the writers had finally left a loose end hanging, but it turns out I had just missed one detail about halfway through.

This episode, and the rest of the series, are great. However, when I was watching the first episode of this season I noticed that the screen would go black and I figured that a possible explanation was that it was in response to a commercial break. So, you'll watch up until a point when a commercial break will hit and then get stuck with a black screen, instead of watching commercials. Whilst not having to watch commercials is great getting stuck with a black screen for even 2 straight minutes is not, especially when people can compare Amazon Instant Video to Netflix. People, when watching something through this, or Netflix, usually are looking for the episode to play straight through with little or no delay. Meaning, no black screen at all. Personally, I think the people who uploaded these episodes needed to go over them and cut out the black parts. Worse still, I know because I've seen the entire series through Netflix, there is at least one part that was cut out in this series. There was a conversation between Major Shephard and a future friend soldier before he first went through the Stargate at Stargate Command on Earth where, I believe, Major Shephard asked how it felt going through. This was just one I found, there may or may not be others. I would hope not.
Whilst the fact that Amazon provided people with the Stargate Atlantis series is great and I'm very happy I can watch it through here I'd like it more if the people who loaned it, or whatever they did, kept everything that was in the series the way it was, but took out the black screen parts which may be commercial breaks. If they could mimic what Netflix did with the series I would give this series, on Amazon, five stars hands down, especially having HD as well, however, because of this I'm taking a star off.
Thank you Amazon for providing this series to us, but I would like a better job done if possible.
Edit: Someone else already spoke on this topic. Thanks to other person. However, the cut out of the talk between Major Shephard and the other guy in front of the Stargate was one I wanted to see so I'm still disappointed.

A previous reviewer noted the poor editing of the series opener and part two. I will confirm the disconcerting issues: the opening sequences actually play twice; once several minutes into the content and again after the ending credits. There are several breaks lasting about 3 minutes each, with no transitions, no content, in the episode 1 play.

The entertainment factor and story is done well in the series opener. Parts 1 & 2 flow nicely and builds the suspense! The first 2 episodes set the stage for the remainder of the season and series. So if you can tolerate the poor editing of the first 2 episodes of the Amazon video offering, you will be rewarded for a great SG-1 spinoff saga!

For Season 1, Episode 1 and 2 have some editing problems.  On Amazon Instant Video there are 2-3 minutes of black screen throughout the episodes, I'm assuming where the commercials would have been.  The formatting seems to have been corrected by episode 3 and beyond.

Starts off with one minute of colored bars and varying pitch tones, followed by technical description of the video feed.  The show begins around the 2 minute mark.  But wait, there's more weird stuff.  The "commercials" haven't been cut out, you get to watch 2:30 minute or 3:00 minute black screen intervals.  Bunch of weird stuff at the end too, but I haven't bothered wasting my time on any of it.  Preview for the next episode, then it sort of replays, but without sound.

Overall, I like the series ok, but the presentation is HORRIBLE.

Remember, the show starts at the 2 minute mark, and you need to fast forward either 2.30 or 3.00 minutes for the commercial breaks.

A lot of SG1 fans (and I am one of the fans of the older series too) seem to have initial problems making the transition to Stargate Atlantis, expecting more of the same, just taking place somewhere else. The characters are "deep", some far from heroes, but really human (and the interaction containing a lot of humour) and the Atlantis universe full of discoveries to be made, races and civilisations to meet. Stargate Atlantis gets off to a great start in the Antarctic, but after moving an entire crew of explorers to another galaxy, they lose no time in stargating to another Northwestern American set (the location of most of the stargate adventures). There they encounter a new civilization that speaks flawless English and warns of the Wraith, a new enemy the explorers don't ask a lot of questions about. Instead, they stumble into a nest of the nasty creatures -- life sucking aliens who also speak English, albeit with a more menacing growl. Not only that, having been warned of how bad, how formidable and how utterly evil these Wraith were, they all split up and into small groups and wake the creatures up! Now they, too, must battle for their lives through five seasons of fun, games and shooting ten-shot Berettas at this new enemy. Unfortunately, the biggest enemy is glitches on the DVDs that cause the image to freeze, then turn off the player (at least it did on mine...repeatedly...and other DVDs work fine. I may have gotten a bad batch. Who knows?) But I got tired of having to restart the shows. As for the episodes themselves, some are as irritating as some of the 60-ish STAR TREKs (WARNING: If they have kids in them...especially with recurring actors...just go to the next episode.) Another minor irritation with Stargate episodes is recurring sets -- sets you saw repeatedly in SG-1 shows!) In some cases you can say, "Hey, that's the field where that alien ship was buried," or "that's the set where the Jaffa camps were!" In a new galaxy that's really something you'd expect from amateur film makers with 8mm cameras (before video). But you just have to suspend disbelief. Or belief. Whatever. Anyway, the characters make up for the rest of the cheesy stuff. I also get sick of the extras sitting around in conversations, watching the main players, but never uttering a word. Guess that's because you'd have to pay them. Oh, well. Buy 'em anyway...if you can get them to work.

I would recommend the series for anyone interested in Sci Fi.
