This is a good family type series.  SG1 (StarGate 1) takes place "near" the MilkyWay galaxy.  SGA (StarGate Atlantis), uses an additional chevron (place on gate) to go to the Pegasus galaxy.  It is full of fun, humor, good stories, great characters, and great villians.  This is the 1st season and it is when they are cut off from earth.  Extras are mostly, commentary of the episodes.  There are also some behind the scenes sections.  Definitely a feel good show.

Star gate Atlantis
In galaxy far far away a more modern adventure takes place. A team from earth travel through an alien device that was left on the planet earth long long ago. The military of course finds and proceeds to manage the device and use it to explore the universe in an attempt to gain new technology in order to defend themselves from threats more close to earth. A military team with various scientists and specialists' travel through the stargate, which transports them to a distant galaxy in which they establish a base of operations in an ancient, abandon city that is far more advanced technologically then anything on earth. The city is found out to be the legendary city of Atlantis. The team quickly finds out that the city doesn't have enough power for a return trip to earth. Yet the city has enough power to visit plants closer to the city they made camp at. During the their first visit to a nearby plant they discover their enemy in this TV show the wrath. The wrath is an alien species that feed on human by absorbing the life force of the human through their hand. It is discovered that the wraths technology rivaled that of the beings that built the city of Atlantis, and it is also discover that it was the wrath that wiped out the builders of Atlantis.
 The main theme of the show is the battle between the wrath and the human team that went through the stargate. Although several episodes are filler and have nothing to do with the wrath. The military branch at the team is a man named Sheppard who was an air force pilot. But his is the typical tough guy but with a sociable sensitive side as well. His is capable of using his gun and also being sympathetic when it is appropriate. The over all leader of the team is a female who is a scientist and has no military training what so ever. She has step outside the traditional female gender role, she is the typical take-charge woman who feels at ease bossing men around. More then once she had to pull rank on the military leader Sheppard. There are also other side characters such as a buff mach warrior that they meet up with and join forces with. And a more feminine yet still fearsome female alien who provide valuable Intel on the nearby worlds. There is also a scientist here and there that provides comic relief.
 This television show is above average ethically compared to most TV shows today. There are minimal sexual images and references. The violence is done tack fully. And the language is minimal. This TV show is geared more toward the younger sci-fi crowd. Being a break off of the hit stargate and was a hit in itself. Overall this show offered minimal points at which to critize ethically of philosophically. The people attempt to preserve life when they can. They do present some religious aspects in this show leaving it open to a transcendent being. Although their version of this being must work through theistic evolution because evolution is a theme in the scientific attitude of the show. They have mixed current scientific belief and monotheism which some have done. It was probably and attempts not to put off either side of the issue to make their viewer base as large as possible.
 The none traditional female role is something that the west has strongly walked away from and it is evident in the female leaders ship of the team. Although the leader does attempt to retain a little femininity and doesn't represent any feministic ideas. Overall this is a fairly clean and more wholesome show then most today.
A nice journey into the Stargate Universe that follows from the original Stargate TV Series. A must watch for any entertainment orientated Sci-Fi fans.

I bought the first & second seasons of Stargate Atlantis for my son's fiance. She had them on her wish list, so I ordered them.  She opened them & proceeded to play them at my house for the next several days. I got hooked on it from the first episode! Never thought about the show when it was on TV; not a big TV watcher. Even though I never watched the original series, I could figure out what was going on because it shared enough of the plot & actors as if it was the beginning of a new show.

I'm an old Star Trek fan, and still love sci-fi. All the futuristic technology was so well done & believable. The relationships between the characters were realistic, and the dangers were quite realistic!

I guess my initial attraction was spurred by the fact that there is a mythology about Atlantis, & they incorporated that, but the ancestor souls who designed this place came through the portal from another galaxy. They left their portal here on Earth, under the sea, where the south polar cap is now. If you're a sci-fi lover, you won't be disappointed.

Stargate Atlantis is a fun series.  Well worth it up to season 4.

Gisele

This show didn't do what some spinoffs do, which is to take the exact same show and just add different characters. This show found a cast that melded well together, had some incredible humor, and was just something fun to watch in the evening. I have to admit that before 6 months ago, i could care less about Sci-Fi, but this show is something that broke thru the stigmas and preconceived ideas about what I thought science fiction was and now I really know what it is all about. Taking your imagination, and letting loose in the galaxy, but still keeping the characters you hold dear as close as if they were friends. I can only imagine the fun they had in creating the show because it comes through in the acting and how it is put together.

The ordering process was speedy and efficient. I received my DVD in a timely manner and when the DVD wouldn't play in my DVD player, the company issues a prompt refund. I would order from them again anytime.

Stargate Atlantis seems destined to follow Deep Space Nine in terms of the middle child of sci-fi franchises.  Never particularly famous, and not particularly loved, except the "hardcore" fans who will swear it is better than the show from where is spawned.  While I'm sure I'll get plenty of angry comments, I am the hardcore fan who prefers atlantis to SG1.  Why?  Well, Atlantis starts very different from SG1.  For starters, the first season is largely about them learning to understand and adapt to Atlantis, on their own with no help from earth.  They are alone and dealing with a completely new enemy, the awesome Wraith, as well as a few equally evil humans, the Geni.  This feeling of being completely on their own with everything feeling new lends creedence to the "explorer" theme of stargate far better.  While I love SG1, I would get tired of the Asgard saving them all the time.  Atlantis has atlantis and themselves, and must make do.

Better yet, this show truly takes from the classic sci-fi of olden days.  Not just the political references, but the stories that you don't see coming from a mile away (well mostly), with interesting twists, and similarly building the characters and stories along the way.

Best of all, the show is just a lot of fun.  I can watch Sheppard and McKay banter all day long.  Frankly, in terms of scientist characters, McKay is easily my favorite of all sci-fi.  He may be a bit of jerk, but his performance is likeably and fun enough to warrant you truly liking the character.  Anyway, I've said too much, but I highly recomend you give this show a try if you haven't the first season sets a great precedent, and is one of the more entertaining shows you'll see.

I haven't had time yet to watch it, but know I will not be disappointed, I loved the series, in fact it's on TV now and I watch it always. They had a great group. When I get my bills taken care of, I plan on asking for all the series. But not right know.
Thanks for putting this series on for us who love these programs so we can see them when ever we want, instead of waiting until our TV stations decide to run them.
Thanks Verna
I loved it. Stargate Atlantis is brilliant and humorous. Very entertaining and the best Sci-Fi show in my opinion.
The DVDs and case are both in great condition and the price is very competitive. I have not been able to find a better price locally or on the web.

I should start by saying that having watched all five seasons, Stargate Atlantis is officially my second favorite science fiction show (the first being Firefly).

The first season starts out a bit uncertainly, but by the middle of the season I was fully engaged in the show and its characters.  Interestingly enough, when I went back later and re-watched the beginning of the series, I loved it!  The bottom line is - if it doesn't hook you at first, keep watching.

Atlantis is not the best written show I've ever encountered, but its characters are among the most endearing.  The acting is excellent as are the special effects, so I'm willing to forgive the choppy writing.  The flaws it suffers from are common ones: uneven character development, characters magically regenerating from devastating traumas and injuries within the space of a week, characters forced out of character for the sake of a story, and so forth.

But putting all of that aside, I truly did fall in love with this show and its characters, who became like a dysfunctional second family.  Some of the highlights:

John Sheppard - team leader and military commander of Atlantis. Highly trained, highly intelligent, snarky, brave, loyal and protective of his team above all else, Sheppard is a semi-suicidal hero with a dark past and disdain for authority. Sheppard's character bio might sound trite, but he is played with such delightful, playful expressiveness and complexity by Joe Flanigan that he becomes much more.  The beautifully acted Sheppard is an endearing, flawed, and lovable leader.

Dr. Elizabeth Wier - overall expedition leader, in charge of Atlantis Base.  Wier initially seems stiff and reserved, but develops into a smart and likable administrator who even has a positive relationship with the normally defiant Sheppard.  A civilian, Wier lends the expedition a scientific and humanitarian aspect.

Dr. Rodney McKay - brilliant physicist and overall tech/science/mechanical genius who is in charge of saving the day whenever Sheppard isn't doing so.  Initially portrayed as a bit of a coward, the insecure, high-strung, arrogant, and self-centered McKay is the show's best layered and developed character.  McKay shows great courage and loyalty in overcoming his fears, and becomes a valuable, endearing member of Sheppard's team.  Despite his arrogance and biting put-downs of co-workers, McKay is also portrayed as one of the most caring and moral people in the expedition.

Dr. Carson Beckett - A highly skilled Scottish medical doctor, Carson is in charge of all things medical and also becomes a more and more integral part of Sheppard's team.  Carson is a deeply compassionate, sweet, and caring person that one cannot help but fall in love with, while an inner strength and occasionally biting retorts keep him from being a cream puff in doctor form.  Carson is one of my favorite characters - ever.

Lieutenant Aiden Ford - initially a team member, Ford's character never quite developed, and was eventually dropped from the show.

Teyla Emmagan - Probably the most cardboard character of the team, Teyla none the less has some great scenes and contributes to the dynamics of the show.  The hot female leader of an alien race of people, she decides that the best bet for her people's future is to leave them and join the Atlantis expedition.  If John Sheppard is the designated eye candy for us female viewers, Teyla is the scantily clad warrior chick for the males.

The Wraith - anorexic goth vampires, AKA the Bad Guys.  These nearly indestructible evildoers farm humans like cattle and feed on them by draining their life force in an excruciatingly painful feeding process.  Fond of vengeance and growling noises, the wraith are the number one enemy of the expedition and of the galaxy as a whole.  The wraith would love to find out where earth is so they can snack on it.

The Lost City of Atlantis - a submerged/floating/flying city filled with endless undiscovered technology.

Along with a well-rounded cast of likable side characters, this team along with some later changes keeps us well entertained for five seasons, at the end of which the show was canceled for no particularly good reason.

I grew to love Atlantis, and I hope you'll give yourself a chance to fall in love with it too!

One of the big arcs of the "Stargate SG-1" series was finding the Lost City of the Ancients, also known as Atlantis.

It also turned into fertile fodder for a spinoff series (come on, you KNEW they had to make one eventually), known as "Stargate: Atlantis." The first season has its duds and awkward moments -- much like its parent series -- but it proves to be a solid introduction to likable new heroes, a legendary city, and a new race of alien parasites.

At the Antarctic base, Daniel Jackson (Michael Shanks) has finally figured out the location of Atlantis -- in the Pegasus galaxy. General Jack O'Neill (Richard Dean Anderson) gives the go-ahead for an exploratory unit to go to Atlantis -- even though they don't have the power to return back to the Milky Way, and will be stranded there.

So Dr. Elizabeth Weir (Torri Higginson) leads an international group of scientists and military to another galaxy, and arrive in the sunken Ancient city of Atlantis. Unfortunately, after ten millennia Atlantis is running out of power, and soon the whole place will flood. The military unit, including Major John Sheppard (Joe Flanigan), goes scouting for a planet to evacuate to, and encounter the friendly natives.

Meanwhile, the irritable scientist Rodney McKay (David Hewlett) tries to somehow salvage the city -- only to have it rise from the ocean floor. But then the SG teams accidentally wake an ancient enemy -- the parasitic, vampiric Wraith, who destroyed the Ancients long ago. Cut off from Earth, the expedition settles into the Ancient city and tries to make the best of their situation.

Unfortunately, the Pegasus galaxy has plenty of its own dangers -- an energy-sucking "shadow," possible spies, life-sucking bugs, a destructive nanovirus, a mysterious goddess, suicidal kids, cannibal Wraith, and an Amishlike people who turn out to be ruthless soldiers. And the Wraith are closing in on Atlantis, intent on getting to Earth -- forcing Weir and Sheppard to arm the city for what may be its final stand.

"Stargate: Atlantis" has an easier introduction than most series, even spinoffs. The whole idea was introduced over a few seasons of "Stargate SG-1," and two of the characters (Weir and McKay) were also recurring characters. And thank God, there is no endless whining about how they may never see Earth again, as many series would do -- the Atlantis personnel just forge ahead, and deal with it.

It does have some flaws, mostly the same ones that "SG-1" had in ITS first season -- a few duds ("The romancing of the alien priestess? It's very 1967 of you"), and many others that are good sci-fi watchin', but not great. It takes a little time for the series to get comfortable, but by the last four or five episodes, it really takes off.

And it has plenty of sci-fi staples -- ugly nasty aliens, tightly wound scientists, little tubular ships, explosions, moral quandaries and a bit of classic-style horror. But it doesn't lose its laid-back style (Rodney massaging his feet during a conference), or its human side -- for example, one episode has everyone recording touching messages to send back to Earth.

And the dialogue is pretty great, with lots of one-liners and snappy exchanges. Most are from Rodney ("This device must be using an older version of Windows"), and Sheppard ("I am your death. That is all you need to know." "I prefer 'Steve'"). But there's humor from everyone ("Find another problem with it! Tell him that the power-loop interface isn't jiving with your walkabout!").

The cast is a bit uneven -- Higginson is given too little to do, and Rainbow Sun Francks just never works. But Flanigan has a nice O'Neillian sarcastic snap, Hewlett is hilarious as the mildly antisocial, ever-exasperated scientist, and Paul McGillion is simply adorable as a cuddly Scottish doctor. And while Rachel Luttrell starts off as just the token native love interest, she evolves nicely at the end of the season.

"Stargate Atlantis" has its shaky moments, and the actors were still getting a grip on their roles. But it's a solid first for a solid sci-fi series, gating out into a new galaxy.

For those who love stargate SG1, or for those who love a good sci-fi show. Stargate Atlantis is just as amazing as SG1. with old and new characters in a whole new setting is just one interesting episode after another. altho i may seem partially bais, I'm an enormous stargate fan.

I have always liked the Stargate programs, from the original movie to SG-1. But, while I liked SG-1, I lost interest after about the fifth season. When Stargate Atlantis first premiered, I did not watch it, as so often a good series is beaten to death in attempt by the film companies to milk them for all they're worth. So, I did not actively start viewing Stargate Atlantis until it was well into its fourth season. I was truly 'captured' by the series then, and could not wait to get the seasons I had missed. Thank heavens for dvds! Season 1 is awesome, and Atlantis has brought a freshness back to the story that it had lost.

I think we have SG-1 to thank for the strong, running start Atlantis was given. Because we didn't have to do what SG-1 did--which was introduce nearly the entire concept of the Stargate to audiences--we had a strong foundation already created for the sister show. However, Atlantis did very well at not closely mimicking its predecessor but taking an idea already created and expanding it, literally, into an entirely new galaxy.

Though I still hold that season 2 is probably the best of all five SGA seasons, season 1 gave Atlantis the strong foundation it needed to become a truly remarkable television series. The characters were strong and evolved over the course of twenty episodes to become people we could really relate with, care for, love, hate, sympathize with, laugh with and hurt for. As I will always openly admit, McKay is my favorite character and I thought he got a great start with episodes like Hide and Seek, The Storm and the Eye, The Brotherhood, Home, The Defiant One and Hot Zone. However, this was also a great season for seeing John Sheppard really come into being as a great character, especially in all the episodes mentioned above. Season one really saw the beginning of what becomes, what I think is, one of the greatest friendships in the Stargate universe.

One of the things that made this season so great (and so different from all the others) is the concept of this team of explorers being completely isolated from their predecessors. With literally almost no ties to the show that began it all, season one of Stargate Atlantis was allowed to come into its own with nearly no interference from the show that began it all. I think that is one of the things that really helped make SGA strong. SG-1 was a great show, one of the best and hard to beat, but we needed to know that we were not just getting a repeat of the first eight seasons of SG-1 set in another galaxy. I think fans were pacified after the first few episodes.

Season one was nearly perfect as an introductory season. The writers, cast and crew did a wonderful job at giving us something both familiar and unique.

In my opinion acting and casting are not good in this sci-fi. Altough there are some interesting episodes, most of the scenes are in stereotypical settings. Outdoor scenes are sometimes illustrated with artificial paintings, which is dissapointing.

I purchased the 4 season set of Atlantis at Amazon, at an amazing price.

The DVD set
1.  Disc 4 did not work on my Home Theater but it played OK in my DVR.
2.  The menu is hard to understand and there are no scene selection.

The Series:
1  The series is GREAT.
2. It was a bit slow at the beginning, but it picks up by season's end.
3. The special effects are OK, and at times AWESOME.
4. The characters are fun, and a welcome change from the typical SNG, DS9 and Voyager types.  I am a fan of those shows as well.
5. The main villain and secondary threat are very unique.  The main at times we need more background, but I can see how they are flesh out more on season two.  The introduction of the supporting villain is  something to think about for the Atlantis crew.  Not everything is fun in the Pegasus Galaxy and not everyone welcomes humans.
6. Actually I do not understand the language issue.  Everyone in Pegasus speaks English or did they explained this on SG-1.  I know that in the Star trek Universe the communicator works as a translator both ways.  But here is never explained, so it does not sit well with this reviewer.

I strongly recommend the series.  The four star rating becuase of the problem with the set.
as a stargate fan from the original movie to the sg-1 series and now Atlantis I highly recommend this series to any sci-fi lover out there.

I'm one of the biggest Stargate fans so lets say FIEND!! lol I love Stargate Atlantis the most!!! Its extremely hard to find seasons 1,2, and 3 around where i live. Heck, it's hard to find anything you want around here!! I'm very glad that Amazon has these items!!! I've wanted to try and complete my SG-1 and Atlantis Collection and try to find the most coolest collectibles and clothes and patches etc. When i found this stuff on amazon.com i was estatic!!! They've got some of the killerest stargate items i've ever seen and never knew existed!! Killer service and killer items to select through. I have found it hard to decide on what to order everytime i have so far. Its hard to make up my mind on exactly what i want to get at each time!! lol Everything i've ordered from amazon.com has arrived in half the time expected. Everything is in perfect condition and sent with extra care!!! Thankyou sooo much Amazon.com for helping fanatics like me collect all the awesome stuff that makes me happy!!! lol Thank You for your great service Amazon.com

Season 1 provides Stargate loves with new exciting villians!  I was still sad to watch Stargate Atlantis knowing that Stargate SG-1 would soon be over but it was really excellent to know that the spin off had awesome scene's and villians.
Being a fan of SG-1, this is a nice follow up. Caracters well developed, well written stories, super special effects. It's fun to watch.

I think the Stargate series (both Atlantis and SG-1) are great. I already had seasons 1-10 for SG-1 and had watched all of the dvd's several times. So I decided to get the season 1 of the Atlantis shows. I purchased the box set from iNetvideo along with other dvd merchandise from other sellers. iNetvideo's shipment was delivered within a couple of days prior to the the deadline date. And the shipment arrived more than week after I had already received the merchandise from the other sellers eventhough the same shipping method was used.

After inspecting the merchandise and playing only the first dvd, I did gave an excellent seller's feedback. When I finally was ready to play the 5th and last dvd I instantly realized that something was wrong. The exact same episodes that are on Disk 1 Volume 1 were on Disk 5 Volume 1. I removed the dvd from the player and looked at the label - the label said Disk 5 Volume 1. I read the DVD case cover and it listed the episodes that were suppose to be on that disk but were not.

Now, how one dvd can get mislabeled and placed into a 2005 box set without a massive recall because other customers experienced the same problem is strange to say the least. My girl friend and I have order quite of few dvd through Amazon's website and this is the first time there has been a problem. I removed the feedback that I had previously give and contacted the seller via the Amazon website about this defect.

After two and no response from the seller, I contacted Amazon. They quickly responded and taking care of the situation with their A-Z guarantee. Meanwhile, I have download the last 4 episodes using Amazon's Unbox feature. I want to view these esipodes and found out what happens. I really like this series - it's as good as SG-1. Great originality in the storylines. There's actiion, humor and sometimes a tear jerker (my girl friend, of course). The characters every once in awhile make a comment about Star Trek (in a good way - I like Star Trek, too).

After I am refunded, I'll be returning the box set to the seller and will probably just download the rest the season 1. Lesson learned - watch all the dvd's before giving a seller's rating. I'll be purchasing season 4 but not from this seller regardless of what their prices are.
It has been a long time since I saw a good sci-fi show. Atlantis is really smart and entertaining right from the start.

Well, I *wanted* to like it, really I did. The effects were gorgeous, the premise wonderful... the writing abysmal, and the acting about 50-50. And when I say 50-50, I don't mean average; I mean 50% excellent and 50% forehead-slappingly bad.

If you loved the original series... you can watch this, but don't expect the same high quality, competence or intelligence.  The writers are evidently rehashing old sci-fi standard plots, one at a time, without comprehending the basic premise behind the originals. I'm afraid we were yelling at the TV in disgust at one point. Writing characters who wouldn't be able to survive due to being too dumb to live on this world does not make me believe in their ability to make it on another.

It does get better, a little. If you can sit through the worst of it in the beginning they start to manage a couple better episodes towards the end. Now, if we can just some up with a way to assassinate that idiotic commander chick, it might all turn out ok. (I can only blame so much of her character on the writers having no clue of the leadership qualities necessary to run a remote scientific/military outpost. The rest is just bad acting.)
This is a great show as long as Ben Browder stays off of it.  It is a great follow up series with Stargate SG-1.  A must have for any Sci-fi fan.

When I watch television I do so to escape.  I'm annoyed with all the reality shows and do not find them entertaining.  I much prefer escaping to the Pegasus Galaxy for an hour or so.  The writing for the Stargate Franchise is still strong.  I hope they continue for many many years.  Atlantis is my favorite so far, even with life-sucking aliens at every turn. The Atlantis characters are all well written and the actors are portraying them are awesome.  Keep the awesome episodes coming!

Stargate: Atlantis was my first brush with the Stargate franchise - aside from having caught the dismal original movie on air - and I honestly didn't expect much. Being a huge science fiction fan, I expected to have seen most of it done better before. Well, it's all been done before, but never quite like this. The series takes all the clichs and stock plots, and put its own spin on it entirely. It has charm. It knows its own weaknesses and doesn't hesitate to throw a few wry comments into the cam. The characters are marvellously flawed and realistic most of the time, and delightfully witty to boot. The plots are hackneyed and old, but executed to near-perfection, and strung along into a coherent arc.
It's not the most original thing in the world, but it's fresh. If you're not a die-hard SF fan, you most likely won't be converted, but if you're new to the genr and like what you see, this ought to be your first stop, and if you're already fed to bursting and starting to get sick of Star Trek and Doctor Who, then this might just remind you why you loved them in the first place.

This is the best season of Stargate Atlantis by far. It breaks away from SG-1 and creates a whole new environment and new characters. Although Weir is really annoying. Sorry but i don't think she can act. Ben Browder was meant to be in Joe Flanigan(John Sheppard) place but he was fiming Farscape at the time. He would have been a nice addition but Joe Flanigan actually works well in Atlantis. I still miss the old SG-1.

I'm not going to review the story. Others have done it and done it well.  I  do like the show even though I'm not familiar with Stargate SG-1.

The special features include a transport chamber (previews, set tour), audio commentaries, and a production design and photo gallery.  The audio is in english, spanish, and portuguese.  The subtitles are in english, spanish, portuguese, and french. All episodes are subtitled.

The picture is nice and clear. The dvds play fine on my old dvd player.

Stargate Atlantis does a great job of contining the legacy that Stargate SG-1 started. New aliens, new galaxies, and new cast make Stargate Atlantis a "must see" for anyone who likes Stargate SG-1 or is simply a sci-fi fan.
Great series!  I have always enjoyed it and have recently gone back to enjoy the earlier episodes.

What is Stargate Atlantis?

Stargate Atlantis is an offshoot of the popular (though now canceled) television show, Stargate SG-1. It follows the adventures of a band of explorers who enter the Pegasus Galaxy through means of an ancient traveling device known as the Stargate. Once there they find themselves in the lost city of Atlantis, and within several hours of setting up base, they tick off the locals, nearly destroy Atlantis forever, are not able to call back home and awaken the most feared and terrible enemy known to mankind, the Wraith.

The team of explorers then come together to create a force against the Wraith, fighting them with all the help Earth is able to give, in terms of both technology and Earth's people, who are shown as caring and brave. They set out to win the hearts of the people of the Pegasus Galaxy, offering help where ever they can, learning new techniques and secrets from a myriad of different cultures and civilizations.

Stargate Atlantis is a very good watch. The graphics are very nice, the characters are sci-fi believable and endearing. The Wraith make for some very good bad guys and the story lines are enjoyable. The first season is a little shaky, in terms of figuring out story-lines and character developments, but all issues are quite grounded by the second season.

It's not necessary to know or have seen the Stargate SG-1 series to enjoy Stargate Atlantis, as the Stargate SG-1 characters make only a brief cameo appearance in the first episodes of this season. However, in the second and third season of Atlantis, they come in quite a bit more. So some knowledge of the SG-1 is helpful, thought still not necessary to enjoy Atlantis.

Little kids will find this show too scary, as the Wraith are a species of albino looking aliens that "feed"  by draining the life force out of humans. Some of the story lines are a little complex for the younger viewer as well. But what you won't find in Atlantis are scantily clad women bearing their all. One of the things that makes Atlantis an awesome show. Respect for the characters.

 As a connoisseur of Science Fiction, I rate the Stargate series as one of the best on television. Endearing characters, enjoyable story-lines and great graphics all add up to make this the kind of show you want to have in your collection.

This is so amazing. Features include random commentaries, a pretty nifty photogallery, among a few other little things. Honestly, my favorite thing about it is the high quality of picture, it makes it great for taking screencaps or just enjoying it in general.

A worthy DVD package if you want the first season of the best sci-fi show out there!

So Dr. Elizabeth Weir (Torri Higginson) leads an international group of scientists and military to another galaxy, and arrive in the sunken Ancient city of Atlantis. Unfortunately, after ten millennia Atlantis is running out of power, and soon the whole place will flood. The military unit, including Major John Sheppard (Joe Flanigan), goes scouting for a planet to evacuate to, and encounter the friendly natives.

Meanwhile, the irritable scientist Rodney McKay (David Hewlett) tries to somehow salvage the city -- only to have it rise from the ocean floor. But then the SG teams accidentally wake an ancient enemy -- the parasitic, vampiric Wraith, who destroyed the Ancients long ago. Cut off from Earth, the expedition settles into the Ancient city and tries to make the best of their situation.

Unfortunately, the Pegasus galaxy has plenty of its own dangers -- an energy-sucking "shadow," possible spies, life-sucking bugs, a destructive nanovirus, a mysterious goddess, suicidal kids, cannibal Wraith, and an Amishlike people who turn out to be ruthless soldiers. And the Wraith are closing in on Atlantis, intent on getting to Earth -- forcing Weir and Sheppard to arm the city for what may be its final stand.

"Stargate: Atlantis" has an easier introduction than most series, even spinoffs. The whole idea was introduced over a few seasons of "Stargate SG-1," and two of the characters (Weir and McKay) were also recurring characters. And thank God, there is no endless whining about how they may never see Earth again, as many series would do -- the Atlantis personnel just forge ahead, and deal with it.

It does have some flaws, mostly the same ones that "SG-1" had in ITS first season --  a few duds ("The romancing of the alien priestess? It's very 1967 of you"), and many others that are good sci-fi watchin', but not great. It takes a little time for the series to get comfortable, but by the last four or five episodes, it really takes off.

And it has plenty of sci-fi staples -- ugly nasty aliens, tightly wound scientists, little tubular ships, explosions, moral quandaries and a bit of classic-style horror. But it doesn't lose its laid-back style (Rodney massaging his feet during a conference), or its human side -- for example, one episode has everyone recording touching messages to send back to Earth.

And the dialogue is pretty great, with lots of one-liners and snappy exchanges. Most are from Rodney ("This device must be using an older version of Windows"), and Sheppard ("I am your death. That is all you need to know." "I prefer 'Steve'"). But there's humor from everyone ("Find another problem with it! Tell him that the power-loop interface isn't jiving with your walkabout!").

The cast is a bit uneven -- Higginson is given too little to do, and Rainbow Sun Francks just never works. But Flanigan has a nice O'Neillian sarcastic snap, Hewlett is hilarious as the mildly antisocial, ever-exasperated scientist, and Paul McGillion is simply adorable as a cuddly Scottish doctor. And while Rachel Luttrell starts off as just the token native love interest, she evolves nicely at the end of the season.

"Stargate Atlantis" has its shaky moments, and the actors were still getting a grip on their roles. But it's a solid first for a solid sci-fi series, gating out into a new galaxy.

I really like SG Atlantis, I think that it may be better then the SG1 series but that might just be that the raith the villans in Atlantis are much less comical then the gould from SG1, however I missed the mix of history and SCI-FI from the first series. Anyway if you like space and Sci fi stories you will like this series

For quite a long time, I never liked Stargate; but now, after seeing Atlantis, I realize that I was very wrong. Everything about this show is almost perfect--almost perfect acting, strong storylines, and incredible special effects!

First of all, the actors:

Joe Flanigan is great as John Sheppard; he gives the character a wry twist, somewhat like Jack O'Neill but a bit less ironic. Rainbow Sun Francks makes Aiden Ford likeable and goodnatured, but willing to take charge when needed. Torri Higginson is better at playing Elizabeth Weir than her SG-1 predecessor, although her character isn't very interesting until the 14th episode. Rachel Luttrell is calm, cool and collected as Teyla. And, of course, David Hewlett, as Rodney McKay, is both annoying, endearing, and hilarious! As for supporting actors, some of the best are Paul McGillion as Dr. Carson Beckett, David Nykl as Dr. Radek Zelenka, and Craig Veroni as Dr. Peter Grodin.

Each of the episodes are very well written. SPOILERS FOLLOW for anyone who hasn't seen them!

1: Rising. 10/10. This episode starts off the adventure very well, with Daniel Jackson figuring out the riddle of the Lost City. We get to see the city quietly hiding underwater and, even better, erupting upwards in a blaze of sunlight. Colonel Sumner's militaristic personality makes us appreciate Sheppard even more. We meet the Wraith, run away from the Wraith, and in the end realize that we haven't seen the last of them. It sets the stage for the stories to come.

2: Hide and Seek. 9/10. Very, very interesting. Of course, it's regrettable that the whole problem was started by some foolish kids, but otherwise it's great. The entire scene with Rodney and his personal shield is one of my favorites!

3: Thirty Eight Minutes. 10/10. This has a tense feel to it. Sheppard's strength is ever so slowly being sucked away by a hideous bug, but no one can help him because their 'shuttlecraft', the Puddle Jumper, is stuck in the Stargate! Tensions rise and, surprisingly, the whining Dr. Kavanaugh helps more than he hurts.

4: Suspicion. 7/10. Okay, but not one of my favorites. The constant mistrust of Teyla's people, the Athosians, in season 1 gets to be annoying.

5: Childhood's End. 9/10. This episode is pretty interesting, involving a group of children and some more Ancient meddling. Sheppard's team gets in trouble, but ends up unscathed.

6: Poisoning the Well. 7/10. The biggest problem with this episode is the fact that the Hoffans--a people who are willing to die uselessly in order to keep the Wraith away--are not the only stubborn ones in the Pegasus Galaxy. They totally refuse to find a better way to fight the Wraith, and that is quite frustrating.

7: Underground. 8/10. This episode introduces the Genii, militant people who pretend to be farmers and fool even Teyla. Although not one of the best Genii episodes, it's all-around strong, especially with Colm Meaney giving a great performance as Cowen, leader of the Genii.

8: Home. 9/10. The team finds a gate with a supposedly unlimited source of power and thinks they can use it to go back to the Milky Way, but of course problems arise. Surprisingly, this episode is not quite as predictable as you might think! Near the end you slowly begin to realize just what's going on, but throughout the entire episode, you're fully in the dark.

9: The Storm. 10/10. This is one of the best episodes in the series so far. A giant storm threatens Atlantis--they begin to prepare--but they'll have to fight off the Genii first! Rodney and Dr. Zelenka come up with a great way to temporarily defend the city, and Commander Kolya is introduced. A wonderful episode.

10: The Eye. 10/10. The conclusion to The Storm, this is another stellar episode. We see what happens to the city and its inhabitants, and face the Genii. Thankfully, they didn't give the storyline a weak conclusion.

11: The Defiant One. 10/10. In this episode, we first see the Ancient Defense Satellite that's featured later on. On the planet below, a single Wraith has survived for ten thousand years and silently waits... Very nerve-wracking and, in a way, sometimes annoying (i.e. the Wraith figuring the Puddle Jumper out in seconds). Rodney's line to Sheppard: "What are you, Captain Kirk?" Great!

12: Hot Zone. 10/10. One of, if not the best, episodes of season 1. A contagion is released inside Atlantis and is almost impossible to stop. We get quite a bit of foolishness from Dr. Weir, however, who refuses to sensibly deal with a situation, making Sheppard eventually have to disobey orders in order to resolve it. Thankfully, that doesn't take away from the adventures in this episode.

13: Sanctuary. 8/10. An interesting concept, but not so great in the end. After a while, the Ancients lose their luster--stupidly refusing to destroy the Wraith and punishing those Ancients who try to. It doesn't help that the entire episode goes by without the Atlantis team gaining any allies or getting a safe haven to evacuate to.

14: Before I Sleep. 10/10. Finally, a Dr. Weir episode that deepens her character! It's too complicated to say much about, but in the end we finally respect and appreciate Elizabeth. A wonderfully complicated time-travel concept helps to add the sci-fi.

15: The Brotherhood. 8/10. Sadly, this episode is just like Sanctuary. It leaves Atlantis with absolutely nothing, all because of Rodney's big mouth. In a way, it's slightly frustrating.

16: Letters from Pegasus. 10/10. This episode is both escapist and intense. Teyla and Sheppard try to rescue some of the former's friends from the Wraith, while everyone else records messages to send to SGC in a quick data-burst. It shows a hidden side of everyone, which helps to deepen their characters drastically.

17: The Gift. 9/10. A secret is revealed, and Teyla becomes even more valuable--in a way. This episode serves to give us more information on her and her people, so it's good to watch.

18: The Siege, Part One. 10/10. A wonderful, tense, horrific, and dazzling episode. The Wraith finally come to Atlantis, despite the efforts of Peter Grodin, an intelligent and likeable British doctor, who's regrettably killed when the Wraith destroy the Ancient Defense Satellite. No one knows if they'll survive, and there seems to be no hope.

19: The Siege, Part Two. 10/10. Just as good as Part One. A group of Marines show up from SGC, bearing somewhat good news, but in the end it seems that even they won't be good enough to stave off the Wraith. It leaves you nervous and very impatient for Part Three!

All in all, Stargate Atlantis is one of the best sci-fi shows I've ever seen. Even if you've never seen SG-1, you should try to get this. You definitely won't be disappointed.

La saga continua. Arranca a la vez que la 8 temporada de la original Stargate SG-1. Y se fue consolidando, cancelada Stargate SG-1 en su 10 temp.  Stargate Atlantis aun continua hoy en da con su 4 temporada. Es hora de que comiences el viaje, compra la 1 temp NOW!!!
If you like Star TRek Voyager - you will love this. Very creative storyline and lots of humour - which is definetely one up on Star trek.

Even if you have already seen all the episodes, this dvd has enough extras to make the purchase more than worth while.  There are actor profiles, making of extras, and some of the funniest commentaries I have ever heard.

Stargate: Atlantis is an excellent and entertaining show that really stands above its parent show (Stargate: SG-1). This spin off not only has beautiful locations and solid writing, but a solid cast of characters. You really come to love each of them and episodes are dedicated into exploring their real issues and trials. This first season is my favorite (barely beating out the 3rd) because of some of the Rodney McKay centered episodes. All of the interactions between McKay and Sheppard are immensely entertaining. Nerd references and fun abound in this kick-off season.

For those Stargate fans, Stargate Atlantis is a must have!  The have found the lost city of Atlantis in the Pegasus Galaxy and instead of meeting the Ancients, the gate builder, the awaken the Wraith.  A vampire like creator that can suck the life right out of you.  In their exporation of the Pegasus Galaxy they make friends as well as enemies.  They also have cool spaceships, puddle jumpers, left buy the Ancients to help in their exploration.

If you enjoy the Stargate SG-1 series, you will enjoy this spin-off.  Being a big fan myself, my biggest concern was that I wouldn't buy into this new look-alike cutting into the original stargate series--I was wrong.  It is almost completely detatched from the original show, has an all new bigger and badder evil race to battle and has more civilian control, which gives the characters' problem-solving strategies a new perspective.  Plus, they're in another galaxy, and the worlds are completely different!

If you've never seen Stargate before, I suggest you check it out...this show takes off at the end of season 7 on the original series.  Watching SG-1 isn't completely necessary in order to follow this show, but it would help a lot.

One thing about the show that isn't so great is that it seems the producers have gotten a little cheaper on the special effects--the CG is pretty obvious and they use a lot of it.  However, being a TV show, I wouldn't really expect special effects on the same magnitude of major motion pictures.

Also, there's the Atlantis movie floating around...if you're buying the season 1 box set, you don't need to buy the movie.  The movie is just the pilot episode, and it's included in the set, so save your money.

Overall?  Go for it--it's worth checking out at least once!

I really enjoyed the first season of Stargate Atlantis.  Character development was well done and story lines, both independant and overall, compelled me right through to the end.  Can't wait to see the next season!

No, it isn't perfect.  I'm reminded of how awkward some of the very first Star Trek Next Generation episodes were, and compared to that this epic spinoff of an existing epic series gets off to a rip-roaring start.  I love the "Several Million Years Ago" scene at the very beginning of the pilot.  I was totally engrossed, and I wasn't disappointed.

Sure, the new cast took some time to grow on me, but I think the reason the cast did grow on me is becuase the show grew the cast during the course of the first season.  I don't expect perfection with a new cast and a new show.  Chemistry can take time.

Of course, at least half the value in DVD sets is the extras.  The commentaries are as entertaining as the episodes themselves, and there is a smattering of additional documentary type features as well.

The one big disappointment was the "Stargate Set Tour with Martin Wood and Peter Deluise".  It took about five minutes of the juvenile editing and the stupid jokes about sex and drugs to make me roll my eyes and turn it off.  I really wanted to see the set and learn something.

Also, the DVD menus were meant to be cool but are really just a cluttered mess.  Do I really need an animated mock-up of some futuristic control panel with all kinds of stuff changing all the time and with the episode titles buried in there somewhere?  I like the straightforward menu design of the Stargate SG-1 series a lot better.

Still, this first season of Stargate Atlantis is a lot of great entertainment for the money.

whoever is responsible for the writing and general storyline should be doing work for troma.

seriously weak as if it's written for 10 year olds.

Nothing like the original series or other sci-fi greats such as Farscape, Next Generation, etc....

again, WEAK

I was sent a blank tape. I was ripped off.

I wrote to the seller but the seller didn't have the guts to reply.

So this is my 1st bad experience with buying through Amazon or people selling through Amazon.

I don't blame Amazon at all. This was an independent seller.

I really enjoy this series; it makes a good replacement for Stargate SG-1 which was getting a little stale.  I think the whole Ori concept is pretty weak.  Now if we can get a fitting Star Trek replacement....

Anyways you get the complete season in widescreen mode that looks great using a progressive scan DVD player and a HD monitor.

Stargate Atlantis is much like SG-1 with a different cast but it still rocks. The first season is great. It begins with epic pilot and has an epic cliffhanger at the end. The new environment is interesting and offers a lot of possibilities for the writers to play with. The cast is good even though I don't like Weir as much as Hammond of Texas. The humour is still there and it's an important part of Stargate.
This series is great.  The only flaw is that the entire Universe seems to speak English without an accent.  The aliens speak better US English than many US citizens.

My family and I watched the Stargate; SG1 series and loved it. We looked forward to this spin-off and were not disappointed. We watched it each week as it originally aired, and when it became available on DVD, we purchased it to go with our collection of the first 8 seasons of Stargate; SG1.

The concept is a bit overused:  The good guys are outmanned and outgunned by a super-foe that can crush them easily (the winning recipe of SG-1).  The good guys just get by with the skin-of-their-teeth.  Eventually, the good guys win over overwhelming odds (did I just give away the last episode?).

The bad guys, the Wraith (are they trying to get the D&D crowd, here?), look like a cross between the swamp monster and a vampire.  They may not have looks, but they do have everything else.  They are hard to kill, have interstellar travel capabilities, have telepathic ability, have transporters, have phasers, are aggressive, have large numbers, and have beaten the super-race of the ancients.  We get it: they are REALLY tough to beat.

However, I am a sucker for computer graphics and advanced technology.  The CG on this show is very good and the concept of having a treasure-trove of advanced technology goodies to play with appeals to me.  Also, there is alot of stuff to be found on Atlantis, so future, undiscovered goodies are still to be found.

Overall, the concept is pretty good and the stories are interesting.  Worth the price.
The entire first season of Stargate Atlantis plus lots of great extras.  The perfect way to spend a day!

I had watched this program rarely on TV here and there, never was really into it.  Seeing a good bargin I ordered Season 1 and was very pleased with my purchase.  The program, when watched in sequence is very entertaining.  I found myself very eager to watch the next episode.

I'd give it 4 stars, as the extra's were poor but it was such a bargin it gets 5.  Really, I would like to hear about the serious things that went into the making of, rather than some actors sitting around commenting on hair styles.

Overall, I enjoyed it!

I purchased this sci-fi show after follwoing its first and second seasons with great admiration. I must admit Stargate sg1 was pretty cool and I had my reservations as to whether this show would make it through the first season let alone go on to its third.

The fact I only paid very little for this was a bonus,although I did have it on my list of wants. The show stands up to its predecessor and seems to get better.

The dvd is well packaged with great extras and worth every penny.
Based on the same "travel to different worlds" concept as SG-1, but different enough to prevent that "seen it before" feeling. Definately worth watching.

I thought that I would never enjoy Stargate Atlantis after seeing an episode of SG-1 co-starring Dr McKay.  However, I am now hooked and cannot wait till Season 2 is released in March.  There are a few episodes that lack a little excitement, but overall this DVD is worth buying.

If you are a fan of the series, then you need to get this set. I don't pay much attention to the Extras.

I like to view any series in order and a season set allows that. If you are not a big fan of the series, why bother?

I'm not going to go into detail about the story, because the editorial already does that. Just thought I'd mention, FWIW, that I personally couldn't stand the original Stargate movie or SG-1 series - BECAUSE of the military/action emphasis. I'm more of a Next Generation/Babylon 5/Deep Space 9 fan, and when I started catching episodes of the second season of this in Australia I was rather amazed. This is from the same people? I mean, yes, they lay the Star Trek jargon on with a trowel, and it's inferior to the best ST series, but for my tastes it was a huge improvement over the original SG series, which I didn't enjoy at all.

So there you are -  a positive review - but from someone who didn't like the original series. Make of that what you will (probably a lot of 'this wasn't helpful's, because I dissed the first one :)

I would have given it 3.5 if we could do inbetweenies.

I bought Stargate:Atlantis sight unseen.  I had watched maybe 15 minutes of SG-1 several times and just couldn't get into it. But because I love sci fi shows like Battlestar Gallactica and Doctor Who, I took my sister's advice and bought Stargate:Atlantis.

I wasn't disappointed - the show has kept my husband and I interested through all of the episodes we have watched.  We both agree that it's Dr. McKay who makes this show great. There is always witty, comical banter even while the show manages to keep that dark sense of foreboding about the wraith alive. I'm definitely glad I bought it!

The first season of Stargate Atlantis is definitely just as good as the best seasons of SG-1. Only a couple of episodes feel borrowed from SG-1, other than that, this series truly is incredible. Almost every single episode is action packed and full of adventure. The new characters haven't had the years to grow like the SG-1 cast has, but they have amazing potential in the years to come to be just as good as SG-1. They are already on the right track with this season. They have a good list of guest appearances from SG-1 cast members and Hollywood stars. If you are a fan of Stargate, you definitely owe it to yourself to buy this DVD set as well.

I, being a huge fan of SG-1, owning the first eight seasons (nine coming soon), had no idea what to expect from a spin-off, mainly because SG-1 started deteriorating after the episode "Promethius Unbound" in which they introduced the stupidest character ever invented. But, back to Atlantis. Totally new characters (except for Weir and McKay), in an amazing new setting, with lots more technology, is a good setup for a great show; which it is. McKay is just as much of a jerk as when his character was invented (the season five episode of SG-1 called "48 Hours"), and I don't like Dr. Weir that much, but Shepherd is pretty cool and somehow, it all works out. So, where the heck is Season 2?! For some reason the Austrailians get it this November, while those of us in America are getting it "sometime in 2007." Oh well.

This is great science fiction and I agree with all of the positive reasons written here.  The cast is absolutely magical with an international quality that adds depth to the drama that unfolds.  Torri Higginson is perfect in the role as Dr. Weir and to think further on this.......I don't see any weak characters in this highly interactive lineup.  The development of Dr. Beckett from a background role to one of the front core characters was a good move by the executives of the show.  Another big plus in Stargate Atlantis is the fabulous Bridge Studios facility in the Vancouver area and the wonderful forest backdrops.  Southwest Canada is perfect for science fiction shows like this.  This is a DVD set for all SciFi fans.

My family found this series to grow on you. We feel it might have surpassed the original Stargate series. We found it thoroughly entertaining while quenching your desire for drama, comedy and suspense. As with all series, we prefer some characters over others, but we found that the cast was well suited for bonding with the show and we can't wait for Season two to become available on DVD.

This was a pretty entertaining series once everyone involved seemed to get into the swing of things. Needs to stay away from the whole 'new planet full of innocent primitive (english-speaking) humans behind every trip through the gate' routine. I would like to be able to get Season 2 so that I can start watching season 3. C'mon already.

Love this series.  SG-1 is great, but Atlantis can easily hold it's own as an independent series once SG-1 is no more. Loved season one and can't wait for season two to come out on dvd--sometime . . . . eventually . . . .

I enjoyed the first season and got it. Eagerly awaiting season 2. See it for sale overseas in the UK but not here? Tough waiting so long...sigh. I can do other formats besides North America but it's a pain. C'mon guys, I'd rather spend the money here.
If you want a dvd collection you can put on a rainy day or in a room you will be doing something in this dvd is for you. All great episodes this series will go on for awhile.

I stumbled across this show late one night when I couldn't sleep.  At the time, I had never seen an episode of Stargate SG1 much less Stargate Atlantis.  I was taken by the characters and the storyline.  However, Stargate Atlantis is now in Season Three so I thought I should buy the first season.  I am very impressed.  The show is great!  The extras are even better.  There are commentaries on almost every episode.  Not from just the producers and directors either.  The actors, such as David Hewlitt, do a lot of the commentaries.  There are also video diaries and behind the scenes stuff.  It is definately worth the price.  I can't wait for Season Two.
Great being able to watch them one after another with no commercials.  Can't wait for the Complete 2nd season to come out.

This marvelous spin off of STARGATE SG-1 does so many things so very, very well.  STARGATE ATLANTIS expands and continues much of the rich mythology built up by SG-1 by delving into greater and great detail into the Ancients.  In fact, looking at the two shows it is safe to say that the Goa'uld storyline that drove the first eight seasons of SG-1 has given way in both ATLANTIS and SG-1 to exploring the Ancients.  In SG-1 this has involved fighting the Ori, who threaten the Ancients as ascended beings, while in ATLANTIS this has involved encountering and fighting the Wraith, the enemy that millennia before caused the Ancients to ascend to begin with.

ATLANTIS was able to hit the ground running in part because of the richness of the mythology created in the parent show and in part because of the number of SG-1 veterans in the production crew.  Most of the ATLANTIS writers also work on SG-1, including Peter Deluise.  One wonders how Deluise manages to find time to sleep, given the staggering number of SG-1 and ATLANTIS episodes that he has either directed or written.

The cast, on the other hand, is a different matter.  Only one regular character was familiar to SG-1 fans, Dr. Rodney McKay (wonderfully performed by David Hewlett).  He had appeared on a few episodes of SG-1 as an exceedingly high strung, grating, but brilliant expert on the physics of stargates.  He instantly became one of the best things on the new show, marvelously blending technical mastery in key plot developments with a host of quirks that makes him equally adept at comic relief.  The most curious casting development was the appearance of Torri Higginson as Dr. Elizabeth Weir.  This was curious because when the character was first introduced on SG-1 at the end of Season Eight, Weir was played by Sci-fi veteran actress Jessica Steen, who did a great job.  I've heard multiple reasons for why Steen was replaced by Higginson, though the one that seems to make the most sense is that Steen declined the role because he would have meant moving to Vancouver.  Whatever the truth, both actresses have performed the role wonderfully, and Torri Higginson is a major asset to ATLANTIS.  The show is technically headlined by Joe Flanigan, who does a great job as Maj. John Sheppard.  He brings a lot of the same qualities to that role that Ben Browder brings to SG-1, though in somewhat less animated form.  Rachel Luttrell is fine as Teyla, an inhabitant of a world they visit shortly after finding Atlantis.  The only problem with the opening credits characters was Rainbow Sun Francks as Lt. Aiden Ford.  One of the soldiers and a member of Sheppard's team (along with McCray and Teyla), his character simply never developed.  It was as if the writers could never figure out what to do with him to make him interesting and vital, and eventually he was more or less written off the show (though he has returned after Season One in guest roles).  There were several other crucial supporting characters, in particular Paul McGillion as Dr. Carson Beckett.  Like Scotty in the original STAR TREK he speaks in a Scottish accent, but his is somewhat honestly come by, having been born in Scotland though raised in Canada.  One actor who doesn't get quite the acknowledgment he deserves is James Lafazanos, who portrays all of the male Wraiths on the show.

The art direction on ATLANTIS is simply outstanding.  The city of Atlantis is brilliantly conceived and fascinating to look at.  Many of the world's they visit are fascinating.  One of the presuppositions of the show is that the Pegasus galaxy, where Atlantis is found, is dominated by the Wraith, vampire like creatures who feed off the life force of humans, but who spend considerable stretches of time hibernating.  As a result, most of the civilizations our heroes visit are considerably less developed than those found by the SG-1 team.  Also, it is a far less rich galaxy, sporting only humans and Wraiths, instead of the variety of races on SG-1.

The first season wasn't perfect, but it was remarkably engaging from the very beginning.  The only real miss was the character of Lt. Ford (the fault of the writers, not the actor).  The season ended with the first two parts of a three-part extravaganza, with a titanic struggle between Atlantis's human defenders against a massive onslaught of Wraith.  The special effects in these three episodes probably surpass anything that was ever done on SG-1 and led to a riveting ending of a great first season.

Many shows have had spin offs, but I think the SG-1/ATLANTIS pair rival any other pair short of BUFFY THE VAMPIRE SLAYER/ANGEL.  Many spin offs are only lightly coordinated with the original, but that is not the case here.  In Season Two and so far in Season Three the ties between the two shows have dramatically increased and promise to be even tighter in the future.
if you like the other star gate, you're going to love this one.

I started watching Stargate Atlantis when it began its syndicated reruns for Season One.  I am a long time Star Trek fan and can't help but make some comparisons.  Although one of the overall arcs of the series is darker than Star Trek (a pending invasion), the style of writing for each episode is light and seems to be more for a general audience relative to Star Trek.  They seem to place emphasis on entertainment over social commentary; however, you may find a lot of the same story formulas (and titles) used in Star Trek revisited in Stargate Atlantis.  It seems to be a very family-friendly series (few sexually explicit situations, if any, but nothing R-rated).  Be aware that some of the 'vampire' aspects of the show may leave younger viewers with nightmares.  All of the characters have good chemistry together and the dialogue tends to be very witty at times (esp. Dr. McKay and Maj Shepperd.)

There are many tongue-in-cheek references to Star Trek (TOS) in this series.  E.g. Major Shepherd compared to Kirk as 'always falling in love with alien women', a Scottish doctor that always seems to end up sounding like Scotty.

The Stargate series is known for their longevity through the ability to keep costs down; however, the special effects are not compromised.

Like others, I started too late to get into SG-1, but watching Stargate Atlantis does not require too much knowledge of SG-1 to get started.  It's a good fix for those of us who are waiting for Star Trek to come back to TV production.

Wish I could give a rating of 4.5 for this set of dvds. The episodes themselves are great to re-watch in one fell swoop, but it's the commentary by the various actors and directors and creators that make the set such a fun viewing experience.  Almost everyone involved in the show seems to have gotten involved in the act, and they are funny, witty, intelligent people who care about what they are doing and offer plenty of insights, and much naughtiness, in the commentary.

The show has improved greatly and really found its' footing, not to mention increasing the role of one of my favorites, Dr. Carson Beckett, decreasing others' parts and adding a wonderful new character, Ronan Dex, to the mix in season two, and I will definitely be buying that set when it is released.

This season one set is a highly recommended selection.  It strongly demonstrates the high potential this spinoff promised and has now begun to deliver.

Stargate Atlantis is a fun and interesting television series with very appealing actors, intriguing storylines, great villains, and high production values.

This spin-off is awesome, almost just as good as SG-1. The amazing thing about Atlantis is that if you compare their first season to SG-1's first season, this is so much greater(probably because of the fact that the writers are the same and know what they are doing now). The first season of Atlantis is as developed and great as say, the third or fourth season of SG-1. Imagine what it will be like on their sixth or seventh season. One thing lacking is more character development, which was also lacking from the second season, but the writers realized that and they are going to make the third season mainly about characters-with an episode completely about Weir on earth and an episode about Sheppard's backstory and one with McKay and his sister. I really liked Lt. Ford and at first I was kind of dissapointed about what they did to him in the second season, but it grew on me. This is an outstanding season or show in general, when I saw the pilot, I didn't really understand or like it-so I held off on watching the show until the DVD came out, by then I had bought all of the seasons of SG-1 and caught up on the story, I then bought the pilot and loved it, when I saw the entire season I was amazed at how good it was-it is a great show. I recommend it to anyone who likes SG-1 or just loves Sci-fi in general. Sheppard, McKay, and Ford are my favorite characters-I think the new guy, Ronin(introduced in the second season) will grow on me. Great episodes in this season include: Rising p1 and p2, Thirty-eight minutes, Suspicion, Poisoning the Well, Underground, Home, The Storm, The Eye, Hot Zone, Before I Sleep, The Brotherhood, Letters from Pegasus, The Gift, The Siege p1 and p2. ENJOY!!!

With Farscape and Firefly gone, I couldn't get into any other Sci-Fi shows.  I was too far behind in SG-1 to enjoy it much, but I've recently got into Stargate Atlantis.  The characters really make this show; they all have very distinct personalities and are quite well written.  Like any TV show, the eps range from okay to very good, fortunately most of the eps are excellent and two "The Storm" and the "The Eye" are as good as TV gets.  As a plus, the effects are stellar.  I'm hooked now.  Check it out.

If you are looking at this page you are probably already familiar with the show, and if not, the other reviewers have covered the show's strengths and weaknesses completely.

I would like to talk about the dvd set itself.

First off, if you are concerned about the problems some of the others are having with the 5th disc, I read recently that it is a problem only in the Canadian release and not the U.S. release. I bought my copy from amazon. COM (as opposed to amazon. CA) and the 5th disc was just fine. So don't worry about that.

One thing that bothers me about this set is that there are no chapters for each episode except for the ones that let you skip the credits and the reviews of previous episodes. I find that very annoying. Sometimes it's nice to skip to a favorite scene without having to fast forward through the rest of the show to get there.

Also, unlike the dvd sets for SG-1, the dvd's come in the slim dvd cases which hold 2 dvds each. I don't particularly like these cases because I feel if I ever accidently step on one I am going to ruin 2 of my discs. They also don't hold the dvd's very securely and I think over time they will start dropping out of the cases when you open them. Sure, they take up less shelf space, but I'd rather not have to buy another set because a couple of the discs got broken.

The show itself looks great but the graphics they came up with for the beginning of each of the discs are fairly cheesy and not up to the usual standard of quality set by the stargate sg-1 releases.

The set is also a little light on extra's, although I love that there is commentary available for most of the episodes. The cast and crew all seem to have a great sense of humor and genuinely seem to like each other and have fun working with each other. It is very interesting to hear what went on behind the scenes for each episode. If you've never seen the show , don't listen to the commentary until you have seen all the episodes for this season because they do let slip with spoilers for shows later in the season.

BTW, one of the previous reviewers said:

"...you cannot return to the menu if you are in the middle of watching a show."

That is incorrect; I had no trouble getting back to the menu from the middle of the show.

Still, you don't buy a dvd set to get the extras or a particular type of case, you buy the set for the show and this show is definitely worth the "price of admission".

Stargate Atlantis - 5 stars
This dvd release - 3 stars

Buy it, watch it, enjoy it.

Yes...I must admit...I've been a huge SG1 fan for years and I own all the DVD's...but Stargate Atlantis is a stand alone show that will capture your imagination with a great collection of characters and interesting stories.  You will not be sorry when you buy this DVD set, it is worth every penny and you will get endless hours of enjoyment from it....

I became a fan of "Stargate Atlantis" through "Stargate SG1," which I think is a better show. But Sheppard is starting to grow on me, though I wish something would happen between him and Tayla. But I digress.

If you're a fan of the show, this is a great set to have. The set also include the two-hour kickoff show, so you don't need to buy that separately.

However, I have some criticisms of the DVD set itself. I think it was cheaply made, because you cannot return to the menu if you are in the middle of watching a show. So if you lose track of which episodes you've already seen on a disc and start to watch one you've already seen, you must fast-forward to get to the end of the show so you can get back to the menu and pick a different one. That wastes a great deal of time.

I like that the people who made the set tried to come up with an interface that looks like what you'd get if you were flying a puddle jumper. However, they made it too confusing. I still haven't been able to find out if there's a commentary track for each episode, like there is for many of the "Stargate SG1" episodes on DVD.

If I could give half-stars, I would give it a 3.5 because of all the difficulties in actually using the DVD. The shows, however, rate a 4 or 4.5. I just love scifi, and "Stargate Atlantis" is shaping up to be a good show.

For those of us who cannot get enough Stargate SG-1, Atlantis helps fill the gap.  Like most spin-off programs, it slightly lacks the punch and character development of the original, but is still very good.  If you LOVE Stargate SG-1, you will LIKE Stargate Atlantis.
Stargate Atlantis is an amazing TV show.  It is an excelent spin off of Stargate SG-1 which is also excelent.
was surprized at how good stargate atlantis was i thought it would be just an other spin off to a great series in stargate.but this is a very good series in it's own right and a must see!!!!!!!

Really awesome show, great actors and actresses, totally cool special effects and features!!

A must see for all science fiction fans!!!

Now, I preface this review by saying that while I have long counted Stargate (the movie) as one of my favorite movies, I never got into SG-1, not least because it didn't run on any channel we got back in our pre-cable days. Stargate Atlantis premiered the year we finally got cable, and we were fans from the first episode, due largely to the wit of Rodney McKay. However, from the very first episode I have been driven nigh unto insane by one heretofore unexplained aspect of the show: How on earth (or Atlantis) does the team understand any of the people they come into contact with?? Come on, at least make SOME attempt to explain it! Perhaps they covered this on SG-1 and assumed all fans of Atlantis would be carrying over? I mean, is is a Universal Translater ala Star Trek? Translator drone thingies ala Farscape? Please, for the love of all things holy, explain this, because I'll tell ya, I'm buying the whole wormholes-through-space, life-sucking-bug-people, folks-evolving-into-pure-energy thing, but this Esperanto gig the galaxy has going on? That's going too far!

Stargate: Atlantis is amazing. Buy it. But not here, or anywhere else in Canada. Due to a mix up, Stargate: Atlantis was incomplete, as the contents on disk one are also on disk five. The problem is non-existent on the US release, so order this from an American source.

When I first considered buying the series, Stargate: Atlantis, I thought it would be a knockoff of the SG1 series.  It has it similarities but I found it to be spellbinding and a great series in its own right.

The star gate is digital and the entire setup seems more modern that the standard stargate.  The crew interact on several occasions with the original cast but the storyline is focused on staying alive in a hostile environment while in another galaxy, the Pegasus system.  The life sucking Wraith's want to take Atlantis so they can gate to Earth for a new feeding ground.  The players try to survive while unlocking the secrets of Atlantis and the Ancients, all while have a good plot line for each episode, which includes gating to other worlds and meeting new people.

This series might not be as enjoyable to anyone who is not familiar with the SG1 series.

My only problem with the series is that year 2 is not available so I can see how they survived the latest attack in the typical "to be continued" episode.

A note about the pilot, don't buy it if you are going to buy the first year, Its included on the first disk.

I think this series has as much potential as the original series and have no doubt that I will purchase any subsequent years that are released.  That's the highest rating I can give any movie, the promise to spend my hard earned money on buying it.

Simplemente grandioso!!  Desde que vi por primera ves Star Gate , ahora llamado SG1 quede maravillado de la serie y de los viajes en el tiempo,ahora que SG1 esta a punto de concluir, Star gate Atlantis nos lleva a nuevos horizontes y aventuras mas aya de nuestra imaginacion,adentrandonos a una nueva galaxya y nuevos mundos mas aya del sistema solar de la tierra, me atrevo a decir que Star gate pasara a la Historia como lo hizo en su tiempo Robotech/Macross.

Simply huge!  Ever since I saw by first you see Star Gate, now call SG1 is astonished at the series and of the trips in the time, now that SG1 this on the verge of concluding, Star gate Atlantis takes to new horizons and adventures but aya of our imagination, adentrandonos to new galaxya and new worlds but aya of the Earth Solar System, I dare to say that Star gate happened to History since it did it in his Robotech/Macross time.
